Supportive Concepts ⭐

☁️ Editable Template

An Editable Template allows the user to update the template as they discover anything missing or inconvenient about the template. Black: With each update the template becomes more thorough and easier to use.

Autonomy

 RBE as a type of stewardism that violates autonomy

Compassion

 Definition not sufficient?
 Compassion is understanding there is a lack of understanding.
 My reply on that definition
 Action not needed
 Be kind to fellow fools
 Is provoking part of compassion?
 Is the skill of not getting provoked part of compassion? >> The order of action according to compassion
 Empathy is debilitating
 Example of Empathy leading to throwing up
 Empathic definition
 Is leniency compassion?
 Black-or-White judging not malice versus judging compassion.
 Effect of compassion by itself. will exhaust resources

Honorism

 There should be a choice

🎯 Deployment
This step is a final check of the response before deployment. Please start a discussion thread for reviews.
📋 Response Checks
✅ Confirm that the purpose is peacemaking Tanya: Confirm that the response serves a purpose of peacemaking.
✅ Confirm that key terms are defined LRRH: Sharing definition is can avoid/resolve conflicts.
✅ Confirm that the response is not an attack Evelyn: A response that define terms is not an attack when it does not use any derogatory terms and does not belittle people who have other definitions. Tanya: It is okay to demonstrate whether a response is logically valid.
✅ Confirm the tone Evelyn: If available, confirm with Grammarly that the tone of the response is not negative.

Lv7 Robert(+0/day)
This is a project node for the design of Arcacian Quest as a board game. Sasha: Per discussion, this node will mark the design challenges along the way so that we could have a representative quest card for this quest.
🔮 Discussion Agenda 📌
This section is for jogging down any items to discuss that is not already covered in one of the sections. There is already too much nesting so I will make each stage 1 section its own big div.

🔮 TPK Forecast

(No item)

🎓 Design Guidelines

📌 LRRH: We should avoid puns because they are hard to translate.
📌 Black: The card layouts should be stackable
📌 Vivi: Each card needs its own node, with ID for that node.

🍀 Minimum Components for Playtest

📌 Gem cards, Quest Cards/title card, Curse Cards to design

📌 How many cards does the game need? How many does Splendor has?
📌 Would there be more than just the rank card to the left of a place card?
📌 How often to do print test?
📌 Initiative card?

📌 Stage 3 topic: Needing resources through out the game Sasha: That is not a given. I could design the rules so that a player rarely can just recruit a hero without paying anything. This is because I still want the consumable cards to have a use throughout the game, not only in the beginning. I think those resources or item cards should still be an important factor to limit how many quests the player can complete per round. But this is a Stage 3 topic.

📯 Design Communication

📌 Add data-card tag
📌 Design the Arcacian Quest Card
📌 Need more convenient graphics display code

🍀 Expansions & Other Play Modes

📌 LRRH: Could we just play this whole thing on the browser then?
📌 Vivi: Campaign Deck, escape room style card with number, supplementary explanation
📌 Black: Long quest: If a complication card is drawn, the quest takes another turn. Current heroes on the quest are stuck there.
📌 Black: Should the guild use the same quest ranking scale?

Unsorted

📌 Scoring: Tanya: Citizenry, Law, Infrastructure
{"cmd":"url","url":"https://freakonomics.com/podcast/make-me-a-match-update/","desc":"🔗"} Altruistic chain
🍀 Design Review Slides
These are slides for design review.

TRACK 1: GAMEPLAY DESIGN
📯 Project Announcement
I am organizing the discussion in the stages: Game Design, Art Design, and Production. I think getting things organized and coordinating is a Herald skill, so I am using the trumpet icon.
📯 Vision Survey
What is your vision of a successful board game for Arcacian Quest? What features about the game are important to you? 202312251118|Day 1, 202312261450|Day 2

Rank S Design Goals

[1] Educational Sasha: The game needs to promote the Arcacian Principle and make a positive impact on world peace. Sasha: Include all magic bakery guild rules in the game.
[2] Recruitability Black: I just want to add that I don't think the game needs to be "replayable", not it should not be spoiler prone either. I think one effect of the game is that after playing it, you should want to make your own hero card and become part of the game.
[3] Living Game Ivy: Optional goal: The game is a living game, that means the way it represents conflicts and challenges has a real life usage to help people solve problems and make peace.

Rank A Design Goals

[1] Fun to Play Vivi: It would fail as a game if it is not at least fun to play.
[3] Bakery Theme LRRH: The game needs to have a cute bakery theme.
[4] Adventure Theme Zoey: The game needs to have an adventure theme even if most of (or all of) the game is not about killing monsters.
[5] G-Rated Evelyn: I want the game to be G rated.
[6] Funny Casey: How about it being funny? Even if the jokes are on the quest, it should be, or at least better if it is funny at least the first time you play it.
[8] Elegant Version (Museum Edition) Tanya: I want there to be an elegant version of the where each card graphic is fitting for an art book or be displayed in a gallery.

Rank B Design Goals

[7] Game Time within 1 hour Black: How about the play time? I think it should be under one hour.
[9] Interchangeable cards Sasha: The game should also have a property where you could add or subtract cards as you like, and you wouldn't need to add or subtract them in pairs or group (where a few cards work together like key and locks.)
[10] Heroes that can level up Zoey: I want to have a sense that I am leveling up even if the game time is just one year.
📯 Rubrics
Based on the visions, here we list the most important rubrics. 202401051131|Day 12
🕊️ Educational Value
  • Rank S Converting Hostiles. Tanya: It seems that "educational value" and our quest rank are the same. This game has Rank S in educational value if it can reliably recruit a hostile entity into peacemaking.
  • Rank A Swaying Reluctants. Tanya: At this rank, the game can sway reluctant helpers into peacemaking.
  • Rank B Recruiting Neutrals. Tanya: At this rank, the game can recruit neutrals who simply had not saw their own potentials to help.
  • Rank C Empowering Helpers. Tanya: At this rank, the game teaches helpers helpful new ideas.
  • Rank D Refreshes Peacemakers. Tanya: At this rank, the game reminds peacemakers what they already know.
  • Rank E Problematic Content. Tanya: At this rank, the game has errors that could mistrain the unsuspected.
  • Rank F Toxic Indoctrination. Tanya: At this rank, the game intentional teaches violence to create violence.
🎮 Fun Factor
  • Rank S Healthily Addictive. Zoey: This would be like a show you are following and look forward to play the next game or when you know a new expansion is coming out, you would want to replay the old ones. XD
  • Rank C Enjoyable at least once. Tanya: This would be it being enjoyable at least the first time playing it.
  • Unranked Unplayable. Tanya: Zero or one star (whatever lowest), would be unplayable. Such as when the player can't figure out how to play despite them wanting to play and like the game.
🎓 Reference Comparison
In this section we study similar gameplay and compare what we want in our game. I marked this with the scholar icon because this is really studying, which is different from a survey.

Closest Reference

[1] Splendor Sasha: So if we make the game like splendor, we could layout a number of quests on the center of the playmat, then the players will take turn drawing "gems" of their choices, and complete the quests when they have collected enough. The benefit of completing a quest is that the quest gives them a bonus "gem", so that they could always use that to complete more quests without first gathering them.
📌 With optional Key and Lock Black: I thought of having special "lock and key" features, but you said each card should be interchangeable so maybe that is not a good idea. Or maybe in addition to the standard requirement, there is an optional shortcut. And a card could give a standard resource, victory point, and an optional "key item".
📌 With Flavor Text Sasha: With flavor text, which would help make the game funny and actually promote peace concepts using the game cards, not just in how the game works.
📌 With a card funding multiple gem type Black: I think in our case, we need to design the cards to be stackable to show what "gems" are in use because in our case, some cards should provide more than one type of "gem". In Splendor, each card just provide one gem.
📌 With cooperative gameplay Tanya: Recap: It should be cooperative, where the players managing their own peacemaker teams, but working together to complete all quests.
📌 With Hierarchy of needs Ivy: The six gems are replaced with icons that roughly corresponds to the hierarchy of needs: Food/Shelter/Land, Security, Belonging/Love, Challenge, Recognition, Purpose.
✅ Still with quest replenish each time a quest is completed Sasha: I kind of like the excitement that a new opportunity could pop so if you are a player lamenting you have nothing much to do this round, you could get lucky. And I think that is somewhat realistic as it can happen in real life too.
📌 With each round being one period Black: The more heroes a player has, effectively the more cards they may claim per round. The way it works is the players take turn assigning which cards they use to do a quest. But the players do not retrieve the newly claimed card immediately. The round continues until no player has any hero to do quest. Then the "month" or "season" ends, and all player retrieve their cards at the same time. 📌 Allow free trade Evelyn: Since it is a cooperative game, the players may trade or share resources freely.
📌 With Urgent Quests Evelyn: Some quests are urgent and would trigger a penalty if they are not resolved in the same turn they appear.
📌 With local penalty Sasha: The penalty or an urgent quest could be local, with effects specific to the current player or the player who had just taken a turn.
📌 With "Not so far" or "TPK" cards Tanya: I want the next revealed card has the potential to prolong the previous quest that was thought to be completed. Then the stake would be the player suddenly need to spend extra cards or risk failing the quest even when they had already spent cards there.
📌 Reshuffle luck cards back to the deck. Tanya: I think TPK cards should be reshuffled into the deck so that as it approaches the end of the year, the chance of getting TPK increases, and the player can never think that, "there is no more TPK because we already dealt with it for this year."
📌 Difficulty setting Tanya: I think it should be as hard or slightly harder than reality. You always study harder than what is required for a test. Sasha: I think the difficulty can be easily adjusted by removing misfortune cards or cards with penalties.
📌 Leveling up individual heroes Zoey: Support leveling up of individual heroes using the quest card. It is okay for the player to manage each hero's associated cards (hero, class, gear, rank) and always play them as a hand.
🍀 Game Terms
This is a dictionary of the terms used in the game or in discussing the design.
  1. Quest Rank Tanya: The rank of a quest should be about its peacemaking difficulty: Rank S spreads peace to a hostile entity. Rank A spreads peace to a reluctant entity. Rank B brings peacemaking ideas to an accepting but neutral entity. Rank C helps a fellow peacemaking entity. Rank D trains the peacemaker themself. 202401032206|💬 Ledia: Thank ranking is for a skill. If you say successful completition of that quest means the team can reliably spread peace to hostiles, then you can accredit the team Rank S in such peacemaking. Ledia: When you say a quest is "rank S', it means that completing it can get you certified as Rank S in some skills.
  2. Quest Rank Examples

    Rank S (Peace to Hostiles)

    Rank A (Peace to Reluctants)

    202401031108|💼 Immigration Law Reform

    Rank B (Peace to Neutrals)

    Rank C (Peace to Supporters)

    Brainstorming with supporters

    Rank D (Studying)

    Judging what the law should be
  3. Skill Rank Sasha: A skill of each rank can be substituted by four skills of a lower rank.
🎓 Legal Topics 📌
Our game might require copy-free content for distribution or if we pay someone to print them.

🎓 How this game trains peace
This section lists how the game trains peacemaking.
🟩🎓 Meaning of Final Score Zoey: In the cooperative mode, the final score involves deducting points for quests not completed. This reflects the peacemaking intent to resolve all conflicts.
🟩🎓 Meaning of Quest Rank Tanya: The rank of a quest should be about its peacemaking difficulty: Rank S spreads peace to a hostile entity. Rank A spreads peace to a reluctant entity. Rank B brings peacemaking ideas to an accepting but neutral entity. Rank C helps a fellow peacemaking entity. Rank D trains the peacemaker themself. 202401032206|💬
🟩🎓 Real Life Quests Black: Base quests on conflicts in real life. The required parts to complete the quest correspond to actual steps or components in resolving the conflict.
🟨🎓 Teach on card Black: Some game rules or principles about peace could be on Intellect item cards. 202401032206|💬
⬜🎓 Link to Skill Node Vivi: On the quest card or skill card, include a code that allows the player to look up details about the conflict or skill online.
🔮 Gameplay Pitches
These are high level short description to compare different designs. Which one seems more interesting to you? 202401112054|💬
[?] Play as a Guild Master
In Arcacian Quest, the players cooperate as guild masters to recruit heroes and upgrading their guild halls to complete as many quests as they can in the course of a year. The center of the play area are quests and resources they could try to get by sending their heroes. But beware, quests can get complicated and may not be as straight forward as they seem.
[?] Play as a Hero
In Arcacian Quest, the players cooperate heroes learning skills and upgrading their gear to complete as many quests as they can in the course of a year. The center of the play area are quests and resources they could try to get. But beware, quests can get complicated and may not be as straight forward as they seem.
[4] Play as a Town-Building Guild Master
In Arcacian Quest, the players cooperate as guild masters to recruit heroes and build their shared town while completing as many quests as they can in one year. The center of the play area is the modularly expanding town that benefits all everyone. The guild masters earn honor by providing the best amenities for everyone, and by completing quests. But beware, quests can get complicated and may not be as straight forward as they seem.
LRRH: I think town building has the potential to be the cutest, but it takes the most art, so it would be the most expensive design. Evelyn: I like this concept more because the center area is not what the players still need to do but what they have completed together. Tanya: I think town building has the most potential for the player to see parallels to real life, and thus have the most "live game" possibilities. Black: If we can pull off the town-building game, the result would be quite unrecognizable compare to Splendor. But I don't think we can complete this. It just takes too much art work.
🔮 Gameplay Walkthrough 🚧
Unboxing/Components
Information in this section is not correct and needs to be cleaned up.
  1. There are [4] main types of cards: Item cards, Quest cards, Places cards and Heroes cards.
  2. Item cards has 6 types. The player may sort them into six piles, but that is optional because a player may choose which one to take. They are distinctly colored. ⬜🟥🟨🟩🟪⬛
  3. Quest cards has 6 types: Rank D, C, B, A, S and seasonal. Quest cards are Silver ⬜, and the type is marked by an icon on the back.
  4. Place cards are tan 🟨, with map parchment back
  5. Hero cards are brown 🟫, with a wood back
📌 Are there too many decks?
📌 Can we get rid of the six item cards and just use a resource tracker?
TRACK 2: ART DESIGN
🎓 Art Design
This part is about prototyping the layout and other visual elements to see if they are functional for the game design from Stage 1. According to Stage 1, the basic game mechanic references Splendor, and there are at least two different visual styles.
Magic Bakery Manga Style
This is the style where the graphics would be similar to what we have in manga and on the website with an overall brown and tan color scheme. The six icons will still have distinct color code, but we would keep purple instead of blue because the blue color sticks out too much in our normal coloring.
Museum Edition Marble Style
This color scheme is has a marble/grey background, the graphics would be more realistic painting style.

This is a prioritized queue for StarTree. Wee~~!

🍍 Longer Quest card for vertical stacking
🍍 Item card: Art Supplies (1-use)
🍍 Item card: Produces (1-use)
🍍 Item card: Cake card
🍍 Ribbonless Hero card, update layout for comparison
🍍 Basic 🎓 card with text definition (Black)
🍍 Quest card: Correcting immigration law (Vivi, Black)
🍍 Ledia: Still need to "spotlight" card format for profiles
🍍 NG Card
📌 Black: Card layout showdown
📌 Assertive Goodwill / Presumed Goodness / Appeal to Common Decency (Peacemaker) / Muffler card name too boring.
📌 Active Constructive Response card
📌 Burnout countermeasures
📌 Card: Identifying helpers and their rank and status
📌 Icon Making
📌 Make cards in the ideas section.
🔮 Layout Specifications
This section lists what parts of the layout is standardized across cards.
Card Background: StarTree: Cards of things (items, places, heroes) have a pudding theme background. Quest cards have a grey background.
Left Ribbon: StarTree: Quest cards have a left ribbon with a rank letter. It is designed to be placed behind a thing card, showing the rank of the thing. The color of the left ribbon is not standardized, but may have a color code for seasonal quests of the same season.
Right Ribbon: StarTree: A quest card may also have a standardized right ribbon. The icons on the right ribbon corresponds to the effects on the quest, most commonly adding to the overall cost needed to complete the quest.
❤️ Visual Appeal
Notes on visual appeal.

Rank A

LRRH: When you design a card, you should aim for making it something a player would want to eat when they see it. A good card let the viewer imagine interesting possiblities to do with the card. {"cmd":"url","url":"https://raw.githubusercontent.com/MagicBakery/Images/main/Place_MagicBakery_20231229_0440.png","desc":"🎨"} {"cmd":"url","url":"https://github.com/MagicBakery/Images/blob/main/Hero_Zoey_20240101_2355.png?raw=true","desc":"🎨"}
🎓 Flavor Text Guidelines
Per 202312311718|discussion, flavor text should be in-character, funny, and the most amazing ones also describe an optional skill or mechanic.
👑 Best Flavor Text
Magic Bakery Card: Let there be cakes: "Legend has it that a Rank S cake is as good as anything." StarTree: This line is good because it is in-character and it means that when Magic Bakery (or any cake) reaches Rank S, it cake can substitute for any symbol required to complete a quest.
Zoey Card: Let's Quest: "Zoey joins any quest as requested by any guild." StarTree: This line is good because it is in-character and it means that when a player decides to do a quest, as long as Zoey is not already in a quest, the player may assign Zoey to do the quest.
TRACK 3: COMPONENT CREATIONS
🎓 Preparing Emoji
This Stage 3 step is about prepare the Noto emoji for our card (and to upload to the website). Our process adds a shadowed black border to the standard Noto emoji. Please see the 202208012343|assets node for details.
🍀 Card Sleeves
The cards are designed to be 2½ × 3½, which uses 64mm × 89mm sleeves.
If you have sleeves for 2⅝ × 3⅝ cards (which has pocket dimensions 67mm × 94mm), please scale the with of the card to 2.64 inches when printing.

🟥 Idea
🍀 [2/6/20] Item Cards

Tanya: The star rating corresponds to whether the item tends to be effective in making peace with the following target types.
5-Star: Effective on a hostile recipient.
4-Star: Effective on a reluctant recipient.
3-Star: Effective on a neutral recipient.
2-Star: Effective on a willing recipient.
1-Star: Effective on the user themself.
  1. ✅ 202207282137|🧭 Moral Compass
  2. ✅ 202207241133|🎯Checker Shield
  3. 🟨 Art Supplies
  4. 🟨 Assertive Goodwill Muffler
  5. 🟨 202401201702|🎒 Day Pack

🍀 [1/2/18] Seasonal Quest Cards
Seasonal quests need to be completed within the season. Points might be deducted if they are not complete.

    Success if there is a loop, and get rewards according to loops.

  4. 🟥 New Year Celebration
  5. 🟥 Lost and Found snowman
🍀 [3/4/11] Quest Addon Cards
Complication cards are additional costs attached to a quest. Since they are not part of the quest card, they allow more variety to the context of the quests.
📌 Excursion Tanya: This adds a condition where the heroes can't get help in the middle of questing.
📌 Expedition Tanya: This adds a requirement that each hero needs to pack supplies and will be cut off from help once the quest starts.
📌 Extraction Tanya: This addon gives the quest an objective to save a person from a place.
  1. ✅ 202307161217|🕳️ Legal Loophole
  2. ✅ 202401212041|🦀 Magnetized Crabs
  3. ✅ 202207241133|👒 Strawman
  4. 🟨 Bad Weather
  5. 🟥 A puddle of Rainbow
  6. 🟥 Quick Quest
  7. 🟥 Who Authorized this
  8. 🟥 Medic Medic
  9. 🟥 Weather Channel/Complications card
  10. 🟥 Complication: Customization
  11. 🟥 Complication: Not as it seems
❤️ 3B's Drawing Queue
This is a prioritized queue for 3B. Wee~~!
202401302140|📌 Champion Armor
202401172340|📌 Town tile background
Arcacian Quest
Board Game Design
 {"id":"202312251111","parentid":"202207131009","parentname":"Board Games","icon":"🏰","title":"Arcacian Quest","subtitle":"Board Game Design","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2017/06/30/17/23/fortune-telling-2458920_640.jpg","music":"","author":"Sasha","description":"","card-text":""}
⭐
Merry Christmas and Happy New Quest of designing Arcacian Quest as a board game!
📯 Motivation
Sasha: The concept of making a board game to promote Arcacianism is not new, so no one should be surprised by that. But there are two recent events that prompted me to take the next step:
Sasha: 1) Someone made a post promoting their board game that is sold locally. That reminds me that we are supposed to make a game also. Sasha: 2) I happened to get a copy of Munchkin Deluxe, it has some similarities to what we need for Arcacian Quest as a board game in terms of mechanics. I think we can do better. Sasha: So, let's go!
⚖️ High Concept
🎩Sasha: Arcacian Quest the Board Game is meant to be a cooperative game that simulates how an Arcacian society deals with issues in society and promotes happiness.
Game Goal: Year-end Celebration. Sasha: In the game, you play as a guild master and send heroes to complete quests, with a goal of being able to celebrate as a society at the end of the year.
Winner: Guild with the highest honor. Sasha: If you care about the "winner", the winner is the guild with the highest honor in the end.
TPK: Sasha: To add challenge/difficulty, the guilds can lose if they somehow fail and the end of year becomes a time of moaning instead of celebration.
Sasha: This area is left for comments about the high concepts.
🎲 Gameplay & Components
🎩Sasha: The game components will mainly or solely consist of cards. The cards should be the same style as what we display at the website. Sasha: This means we are supposed to upgrade the website so that the cards displayed are game cardss.
Card Types: Quest and Assets. Sasha: There are two main card types: Quest Cards and Asset Cards. Sasha: Quest Cards are objectives that the players are supposed to complete to keep the peace and promote happiness. Each Quest Card has at least a symbol or two of which and how high of skill types needed to complete the quest. Sasha: Asset Cards are cards where the player can use to complete the quests. Asset cards may include subtypes such as Hero, Place, and Item. Sasha: On each asset card are symbols showing what skill type it offers.
Gameplay: Sasha: The game starts with the cards kept in one or a few decks on the table. Then the players draw card and maybe go through a round of drafting (similar to Bargain Quest). Then quest cards are drawn and assigned to places. Then the guild masters talk to each other and send their assets to do quests all at once. Then each quest is resolved one by one. Sasha: If a quest is resolved, the guild master gets honor. If the quest is not resolved, the guild masters normally can try again next round, and/or the place would continue to have the status effect described by the quest card. Sasha: On the table, most of the time there are the decks, place cards and revealed quests at those location, and assets assigned by the quest master to deal with those quests. Other cards that are not deployed remain in the guild master's hand. Sasha: Guild masters can normally trade or give cards to each other except during a quest. But for the sake of having a fair start, I think the players should still start by drafting.
Tanya: How do you keep track of honor? Sasha: When a guild completes a quest, it keeps the quest card which has the honor value. Tanya: And do those honors have a function other than score keeping? Sasha: I think you can use them to bid for assets. Tanya: So far so good. Evelyn: Could we start with a version where we just play as ourselves in the same guild? Sasha: I think the components will be the same if the players play as individual heroes. It doesn't matter if you think of yourself as just you, or you are a team or a guild. Evelyn: But honor is supposed to be tied to an individual, not a guild. Sasha: I think for simplicity you can assume that the honors in your hand corresponds to the total. If you want you can imagine how they are divided. Tanya: If your game allows a hero to be transfered to another guild, there should be some honor being transfered. Sasha: True and let's consider that as part of the game rule. Sasha: The next section will be about what we need to do to prototype or create the components. Casey: Do you not roll any dice or use any tokens? Sasha: I want the base game to use just the cards. There could be official rules on how to use dice and token if your gaming group like those components. But the game itself should be designed to function without them. Zoey: How playable is this over the internet? I thought we are against deck building games. Sasha: I don't really aim to make this game for online play. But there is supposed to be nothing unique about the cards. I think maybe our website can have a feature where you could keep your deck by loading a save file. Tanya: I think if all your components are just cards, it is actually easy to play online at a platform. Those platforms already support card decks. Sasha: Adhering to Magic Bakery mission the card designs are supposed to be public domain. People may copy and play them online, or print their own copy. Casey: If that is just printing there would be no plastic waste. Sasha: I suppose that depends on what kind of paper you print on...
📌 Card Design
📯Sasha: The first thing I want to design is the quest card and the six icons to appear on the quests. The six icons are supposed to correspond to our six peacemaker archetypes.
Sasha: StarTree please start a file for designing the card layout. Card size 3.5 x 2.5, protrait. StarTree: Ready! Sasha: My thought is to add a color banner on the left with icons. StarTree: StarTree made a project and a Hero card and a Quest card. Evelyn: It looks cute and not too crowded. 🤗 LRRH: For the Quest card could you add the Magic Bakery banner on top? Sasha: I want to know if a quest card can have graphics. StarTree could you make a Monster card and a Place card next? I want to see a quest card that has bad status effects. StarTree: Done!
To be continued...

🔔
The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[159] Brainwashing
📯Natalie: Ann was captured by the enemy during a war and brainwashed to kill the nearest person without her conscious recollection when she hears the trigger prompt "Gingerbread Cocktail". If she ends up killing someone on prompt, would she be liable for murder?
Gaia: She was unconscious so she should not be guilty. 44: That shouldn't count because she was brainwashed, so it was not voluntary. Evelyn: I think she is not guilty but she needs help undoing the brainwashing. Natalie: The card's answer is that while some causes of unconsciousness could waive a defendant's liability of murder, states reject brainwashing as one of those reasons. Evelyn: 😖 Zoey: #TheLawIsWrong Tanya: Swords symbol please. Natalie: Marked and added some links.
This is a streak of 83 days! And 25 times in December.

⭐
This is to continue the discussion on the board game design.
📯 Recap
Sasha: We designed some card layout and printed same prototypes. What do you think?
LRRH: I think there are too many words on the cards for rule text. I think the game will go faster if there are no text. Then we also don't need to translate it for different languages. Evelyn: For the "Undead Pirates" card, I think the game shouldn't be so much about what elements can kill undead. So I think that card / quest isn't really helpful. Black: About Red's comment: I think instead of using Munchkin for reference, the game could be more like Splendor. We replace the gem tokens with basic skills, and we use them to recruit heroes and buildings. For cooperative mode, the final score could be based on what cards are left unclaimed when the year ends. Vivi: Shouldn't the cards have space for a QR code? Evelyn: I also have issue with the card type "monster" in the game. I think everyone should a "hero" but could suffer from curses. If we lift the curse, we can still recruit the underlying person. Sasha: If the cards have no words, they would be useless to include on the skill pages. And they can't teach people about the concepts just by looking at the cards. Black: I am okay with cards having text about the principles as long as they don't matter for the game play. For example, if there is a skill card about emotion control, you can name the skill and give a description, but for the game, all it matter is that it has a heart icon. I think we need to abstract away the details for the game to be playable. Sasha: What about translation? LRRH: I would still prefer if the printed components, especially the cards, do not need translation. If you really want to spread principles with the game maybe the text could be on a separate book. Evelyn: I don't mind if the cards have some text as long as they are not very small and I agree with Black that if the text is only for the lore I think that would be cute because it adds flavor to the card. Black: Flavor text is fine. Sasha: Okay, let's talk more about Splendor.
🎩 Splendor as a Reference
Sasha: My complaint of Splendor is that it is too soulness. The components seem sterile and emotionless. It is just really boring. What would be different if Arcacian Quest has a similar mechanic?
Black: A year has four seasons, so I suppose we could divide the quests into different seasons, or at least have some quest pertaining to specific seasons. Evelyn: I can imagine something really pretty and relaxing to play. Sasha: The deck is supposed to be able to deal with serial killers as a quest. Evelyn: 😖 Zoey: I think I am fine with the quest cards having text. I think that helps the context and the use of the game as somekind of train-as-you-play thing. Sasha: That makes two quite opposite design objectives. LRRH: You don't have to make one game cathering to both types. Just make the one you want. First. LRRH: Then make one that is Magic Bakery theme with all icons being pastry. Zoey: XD Evelyn: I would prefer a pastry themed game if it would feature a serial killer as a quest. At least we could present the killer as a cookie person. 😖 Zoey: You mean at least you could sugarcoat it. XD Evelyn: Yes 😅 Sasha: For now I will stick to more descriptive symbols so people can tell what they actually mean in reality. Sasha: So if we make the game like splendor, we could lay out a number of quests on the center of the playmat, then the players will take turn drawing "gems" of their choices, and complete the quests when they have collected enough. The benefit of completing a quest is that the quest gives them a bonus "gem", so that they could always use that to complete more quests without first gathering them. Black: That is a concise summary. Sasha: In our case, instead of color poker chips, each individual gem is a skill card with just one of the six symbols. Tanya: May I ask what the challenge is in such a game? If it is cooperative, what are they playing? Evelyn: I think it is like a puzzle game where you are trying to complete as many quests as possible by the end of the year. If you play cooperatively you can discuss and trade, and maybe some quests are funny and people can laugh about it. Sasha: I think some quests would be destructive, like a fire burning down buildings. If your group is not prepared, there could be a TPK where the game beat the player team of heroes. Sasha: Going back to the original design, I think it makes sense for the players to think of themselves as guild masters. I think it is more realistic that each player is still trying to get the most honor while also taking care of the town. Black: To simplify the gameplay, once you have recruited a card, all should matter are the symbols and the number of them. You would keep them laid down on the mat in front of you. You shouldn't need to pick them up or keep in your hands. On your hands should be cards that you merely "borrowed" from the public. At the end of the game if you still have cards left in your hand it should count against you. Tanya: Instead of four seasons, could we just do the last season to see if it is playable? Tanya: I see that if our style is not cartoony, we can readily use free stock photo images for all the quests. For example, a quest card could just show a wedding, and its requirements are many Hearts, Trumpets, and Cakes. Tanya: It seems that the three tiers of cards could be people, facilities, and events. Sasha: I have a hard time picturing the icons if it is not done in cartoon/manga style. Evelyn: I think the end result would look elegant but not funny. Sasha: It would become sterile like Splendor. Humorless. Tanya: I see. Black: What about the overall gameplay? Zoey: Actually what I want is to be able to have a card that represent me. Maybe even a deck with my skills. Then when I come play the game, the GM presents the Quest, and we see if we already has what it takes to complete it. If not, we figure out what we need to get to complete the quest and thus do subquests. Zoey: For example, right now we are trying to make a game, what is missing or preventing us from completing it? Sasha: First we need to define at least one playable and meaningful design, then we list the components to make, and finally we turn the prototype components in the actual components with correct arts. Zoey: The more people you want the game to be played the more decisions would be needed upfront. After that, listing and making them are comparatively straight forward. Black: I think this is a case where we can't just make a decision in one sitting. So we need to also list what we need to decide. Ivy: Every difficulty you face now indicates a missing piece of knowledge or missing step in your design process. Sasha: But I also don't want to spend too long in design before having something tangible to discuss and compare. Evelyn: How about we make a few examples of a card done for different gameplay? Ivy: There was also an idea that for the game cards to be "realistic", you should keep track of the difficulties you face so that you can use the correct number of icons for the eventual quest card. Black: How would the game handle the concept that sometimes you can't finish a quest in one go and you spread it over different sessions? In Splendor that is represented by the turns you spent collecting gems. Evelyn: I think the concept that making the cards is part of the game is interesting and could be helpful later on. Sasha: Okay. So I need to organize what we are discussing and mark each section with the appropriate icon so that we could account for the eventual quest card that is accurate. Sasha: For simplicity, there are supposed to be only six types of needs, as I list them, I will categorize them, then we can review or discuss if those categories make sense, or if we really need more icons. Tanya: I think that if we count it like that the quest might take 100s of points to complete. Sasha: But we are only keeping the successful or direct path, not including wasted efforts that we could have avoided with better skill or planning. Tanya: It was not a complaint. Zoey: I don't want to see a quest card showing triple digit requirements, please be mindful that conceptually we are holding the skill cards. XD Sasha: I am adding sections to the design node. LRRH: Splendor is "sterile" but people still play it. If you make it bakery themed it would be cuter and more enjoyable. So why not? Little Red Riding Hood does not understand the resistance. Black: That is Kaizen. When you reuse an existing design and just make small changes to make it better for you. If Kaizen is a game card, its effect would be "You may use the challenge level of a previous quest as bonus to complete the current quest."
📯 Vision Survey
Sasha: I started a section about the vision. I don't think we need to keep count of who agrees, unless someone disagrees with the ranking/priority.
Sasha: The game needs to promote the Arcacian Principle and make a positive impact on world peace. LRRH: The game needs to have a cute bakery theme. Zoey: The game needs to have an adventure theme even if most of (or all of) the game is not about killing monsters. Zoey: I mean I don't want to show up in the game as a baker in an apron. I still want to be a ranger or at least a herald. XD Evelyn: I want the game to be G rated. Tanya: I want there to be an elegant version of the where each card graphic is fitting for an art book or be displayed in a gallery. Sasha: Let's call that the Museum Edition. Black: How about the play time? I think it should be under one hour. Casey: How about it being funny? Even if the jokes are on the quest, it should be, or at least better if it is funny at least the first time you play it. LRRH: That is a guild rule actually. Sasha: I'll add include all magic bakery guild rules in the game. Black: That sure is one of the gems of the bakery. Sasha: I think the museum edition does not work with bakery theme and being funny, so I will rank that the last. Sasha: So far there is nothing suprising and at least the top six visions seem compatible. Black: I just want to add that I don't think the game needs to be "replayable", but it should not be spoiler prone either. I think one effect of the game is that after playing it, you should want to make your own hero card and become part of the game. Sasha: What would you call this property? That you would want to be a part of? Black: Recruitability Sasha: I think that is very important so I will put it at priority 2. To me it means that the game should also have a property where you could add or subtract cards as you like, and you wouldn't need to add or subtract them in pairs or group (where a few cards work together like key and locks.) Ivy: Optional goal: The game is a living game, that means the way it represents conflicts and challenges has a real life usage to help people solve problems and make peace. Sasha: This is rank 3 worthy. It is a pain to renumber the rankings so I am just going to group them in S ranking. Sasha is recognized for the skills Survey and Ranking.
📯 Gameplay Reference Survey
Sasha: This section is about what game should we use as reference for gameplay. Here you may also include other gameplay changes.
Sasha: To recap, right now Splendor seems to be taking the lead in terms of what we want. Sasha: What should be different from Splendor, in terms of gameplay? Black: I thought of having special "lock and key" features, but you said each card should be interchangeable so maybe that is not a good idea. Or maybe in addition to the standard requirement, there is an optional shortcut. And a card could give a standard resource, victory point, and an optional "key item". Sasha: I think that is a good idea and goes along with the flavor text. Zoey: It seems that this part of the discussion is only for people who had played Splendor. Sasha: Unfortunately yes. Although you could watch some how to play YouTube. Black: I think in our case, we need to design the cards to be stackable to show what "gems" are in use because in our case, some cards should provide more than one type of "gem". In Splendor, each card just provide one gem. Sasha: I think the card layout designed yesterday can already handle it. But good point. Tanya: Recap: It should be cooperative, where the players managing their own peacemaker teams, but working together to complete all quests. Sasha: Good reminder. Zoey: I like the original adventure theme where you equip a hero and send them out to do quests. But I think in your latest design there are no item cards, just Heroes, Places, and Events? Black: I think Items could also be a type, but maybe it doesn't need its own tier but is mixed with the other tiers. The way I imagined it, the player themself is also a hero, or that when they just use an item to get a card, it is assumed that they are using an unskilled hero to do so. LRRH: Isn't there a fourth type already? In Splendor those are the tokens for the gems. So items can be the resource or consumable items. Tanya: What are the six resources in our case? Sasha: The basic resources need to pay for the lowest tier card, I suppose one of them needs to be food. Ivy: Hierarchy of needs: Food/Shelter/Land, Security, Belonging/Love, Challenge, Recognition, Purpose. Sasha: That fits quite nicely and in icons: 🏡⚔️❤️🧩🏅📯. Compared to what I have now for the color: ⚔️❤️📯♻️🔮🎓 Tanya: I think it would be mandatory for the icons to be color coded. LRRH: Could it be this: ⚔️❤️📯🌳🔮🎓? The recycle symbol seems too modern. Zoey: I thought you would suggest an all bread version. XD LRRH: They would be about all the same color. Sasha: Ripping the tree icon. That tree icon doesn't look quite right so now it is ⚔️❤️📯🍀🔮🎓 Black: I think the trumpet icon seems too thin compared to the rest. Can it be the sun? Sasha: StarTree please take care of the art part. StarTree: Done! ⚔️❤️☀️🍀🔮🎓 Zoey: I think the trumpet is more meaningful, since it means calling for help, so if a quest needs a lot of people it would seem very fitting. Sasha: StarTree please fill the hole of the trumpet with the same color. StarTree: Done for comparison. Sasha: It looks better with the hole... But anyway I want to defer this tweaking to Stage 2. What else should be different compare to Splendor? Black: Splendor has a mechanic where when a card is claimed, it is immediately replenished. That means sometimes you could spend a lot on a card then a cheaper card comes next. Sasha: I don't think we need to change that just yet, or what do you want to change to? Black: I want the players to take turns claiming the cards until they run out of cards, then the quest board refresh all at once. Sasha: If you do that there is no chance for a weaker player to get lucky and get ahead. Tanya: If you rotate or always let the lowest score player choose first then it would even out. Black: My answer is: It is supposed to be a cooperative game. Sasha: But I kind of like the excitement that a new opportunity could pop so if you are a player lamenting you have nothing much to do this round, you could get lucky. And I think that is somewhat realistic as it can happen in real life too. Tanya: I see. Black: Then I want to suggest a change in mechanism where the more heroes a player has, effectively the more cards they may claim per round. The way it works is the players take turn assigning which cards they use to do a quest. But the players do not retrieve the newly claimed card immediately. The round continues until no player has any hero to do quest. Then the "month" or "season" ends, and all player retrieve their cards at the same time. Sasha: Interesting idea, but in that case when can a player take basic resources? Black: At a player's turn they can still decide whether to get resource or claim a card, all whiles the deployed teams are on the field. Sasha: When you complete a quest using consumables, do you immediately return the consumables? If we are simulating reality, they should not be immediately returned because everything happen in the same period. But it will be kind of a mess with all the cards on the table. Black: I think once you complete a quest you can retrieve your cards in a face-down pile. There you could prepare to return the consumables once the round ends. Sasha: Added. Tanya: If the consumables are tokens, it would easier to distinguish them from the rest. Sasha: Defer to Stage 2. Zoey: I think it doesn't make sense for the same player to harvest multiple times when other players in the same period are deploying "simultaneously." Black: I think you could chalk that up to the assumption that a player could actually harvest the entire crop in a month if the others do not compete. I think letting the players choose to just harvest helps with game balancing. Sasha: Yes, I think that is an interesting consideration. I want to see how it plays out in actual game. Evelyn: Since it is a cooperative game, wouldn't the players just share resources? Sasha: I think there should be some penalty on trading or sharing resources. Tanya: I think it would be more fitting if the players can assist each other. I imagine a gameplay where at the start of each round, you hold all of your cards in your hands. When it is your turn to act, you play from your hand to claim cards, and as you do so you form a pile face up on the table in front of you. As the turns continue, you run out of cards to play when you have no card in hand to play. Whether a card that can still be played in the round is in your hand or on the table should make no difference as long as the players have means to tell apart what is already used during the round. Tanya: I am okay with letting the players trade freely without any penalty. Sasha: I'll mark that as a difference. Tanya: Maybe the players can have a protocol where once they have done what they want, they would lay down the rest of their cards for everyone else to see so that can specifically call for help. Black: I think that would very easily lead to the players deciding to just show all of their cards and the game would end up having just the dominant player deciding the main moves. Tanya: If it is not fun the other players don't have to agree to show all cards, especially when the dominant player uses the cards from other players to get points for themself. Sasha: How do you protect the dorminant player from guilt tripping the others for their poor choices? Evelyn: 😖 Evelyn: I am okay with there being no free trade. Evelyn: Or what if some quests are "local" and requires a player to solo? Tanya: I am not sure "soloing" has a meaning when the players can still trade just before or after their turn. Evelyn: No it doesn't. I am sorry. 😖 Black: What about Urgent Quests? According to the status quo, an empty quest slot is immediately replenished. When that happens, the next quest could be an urgent quest. An urgent quest can either be "local", then whoever has the next turn must resolve it or they will suffer from the card's consequence. The other players can still help them. Tanya: I like that idea. A lot. We need something like that for the game to allow TPK. Some urgent quest should affect not just the next player but every players. The details can be described on the card. With symbols if text are to be avoided. Sasha: I think that is a good idea, and at the end of each "round", the penalty, if any, of unfulfilled quests would happen. Tanya: Yes. Evelyn: I like how the sharing vision session earlier allows us to have a productive discussion in this round. 🤗 Zoey: Legit skill at work. XD Sasha: I added about the local penalty. I know it might make the card a little complicated, but I would add that first. Tanya: We need urgency and penalty effect icons. Sasha: Defer to Stage 2. Normally that just means how many or what type of card to discard/reshuffle to the deck. I am not too worried even if the penalty is entirely described in text, since I think they should grab the players' attention and be thematic about it. It is time well spend for them to read the situation. Tanya: I agree. Zoey: I know there won't be an untimely orge invasion. But something like that would make the game like an actual adventure quest game instead of just mining and building. Tanya: Having that would also make oracle skills such as scrying meaningful. Zoey: Then you can literally see the next card "on deck". XD Tanya: Yes. Tanya: I want the next revealed card has the potential to prolong the previous quest that was thought to be completed. Then the stake would be the player suddenly need to spend extra cards or risk failing the quest even when they had already spent cards there. Black: We need the game to have TPK. Evelyn: I can imagine a situation where someone helps you resolve the TPK so they get the credits of the TPK card. 🤗 Tanya: I think TPK cards should be reshuffled into the deck so that as it approaches the end of the year, the chance of getting TPK increases, and the player can never think that, "there is no more TPK because we already dealt with it for this year." Evelyn: I am sorry for mentioning it. 😖 Sasha: If there are bad luck cards maybe there should also be good luck cards, which are also reshuffled, or not. Tanya: If you reshuffle the TPK cards as well as the Save cards back to the deck, wouldn't the urgency at the end of the year just cancel itself out? That would be anti-climatic. LRRH: I want a Santa is coming to town card Sasha: Okay I made another section to log card ideas. But if you can hold it, please just add the ideas there directly instead of discussing here now. Let's think more about the gameplay. What else needs to change? Evelyn: I hope we don't make the game too hard. 😅 Tanya: I think it should be as hard or slightly harder than reality. You always study harder than what is required for a test. Evelyn: Yes. 😖 Sasha: I think the difficulty can be easily adjusted by removing misfortune cards or cards with penalties. Black: But compared to Splendor, this is a notable change, that as a cooperative game the difficulty can be adjusted. We can even suggest training deck lineup. Sasha: Are we about out of ideas? Zoey: Am I correct that in this game, each card is meant to be independent, so there is no such thing as "equipping" a hero? Black: In terms of game mechanics when you deploy a hero with a piece of equipment you are equipping the hero with that gear for the quest. The gear is just not "soulbound" to the hero. Sasha: Is that enough for the PRG theme? You are Zoey. Zoey is a ranger with some skills. The guild master attracts you to join their guild by offering you the raw resource you want. While you are associated with the guild, you go do quest through the player's control. Zoey: But there is no sense that I am leveling up. My level is the same the whole year. Sasha: So you want the game to simulate how not only the quests are being done, but the heroes are also personally growing. Black: I suppose hero cards can be doublesided, and you could flip the card and get the leveled up version. Tanya: If you do that the leveled up version is static. There is no customization on which way you tune their advancement. Sasha: If you really want to "just play yourself" you could intentionally not recruit any other hero, but in each round you are doing just one quest while the other players are doing one quest per hero. Black: I prefer the format where each hero is static for the year. I am okay with each hero having a staic upgrade version on the back, or just an alternate mode. I think this makes the design simplier and avoid different players competing for the same equipment for their play style. Sasha: I think we can accommodate alternate play mode where each player is a hero, and they can collect different gear set, and trade in old set for higher level sets once they have the gained the required EXP (which is marked on the quests). Tanya: That could be a simple mod if the "gear sets" are just always available. So really the player has a deck of customized but predefined level stats. When they have enough EXP they swap the card. Black: The game is supposed to take less than one hour. Sasha: I don't think the time limit matters for a mod. The player can mod it and play as long as they like. Evelyn: I think for the cooperative game, some of the quest cards could require the guild to have reached a certain EXP, then if they choose to do the level up celebration event, the guild could get a bonus because they celebrated and recognized. Black: I like this idea because it is simpler and should be part of the base game. Tanya: I think Zoey's idea of hero level up should be in the vision section. Evelyn: If the effect of the guild level up is that, "Each of your hero has their base stats doubled", then it would be similar to leveling up the heroes since supposedly everyone in the guild would be getting similar EXP as they are helping each other to power level. Sasha: I think that is a good idea. Zoey? Zoey: I think that is better than none but you don't get the detail that some heroes are higher level than the other even in the same guild. Tanya: What about the mod where there are optional leveled up version of each heroes if a player wants to switch them? Zoey: I think that is inconvenient. Black: The other reachable mod/alternative is that as a player once you get your hero, you load the web version of the hero, then when you complete a quest, you can scan or enter the quest code, then the web stores your hero's EXP. You can then assign those EXP to level up basic stats or scan/enter skill cards you encountered to add to its profile. If you want a printed copy, you could export the PNG. Tanya: This. is what our actual quest society need in real life. Zoey: I know if you do it online you can do everything. But I am still talking about the physical board/card game. Isn't there anything the game can do without going online? Sasha: You could make a hero card that is more than just a card, but with a mechanism like a King of Tokyo monster card with dials for you set your stats. Black: Or you could put it in a card sleeve and write the number on it with a dry erase marker. Sasha: That will be like a tiny D&D character sheet. Tanya: Could you tell us what you have in mind? Zoey: Could there somehow be a leaderboard showing how much EXP each hero has? Sasha: Then there can be a mod with a leaderboard. Zoey: What about the base game? Black: Each quest could either have an EXP value or an S ranking letter. Maybe if a party of lower ranking heroes complete a quest, the guild master can spend that card to level up one (or all) of them. This would simulate a rather realistic consideration that if you don't let your heroes challenge themselves they won't level up. That game mechanic was missing in the original design. And I agree that we should try harder to include it. Tanya: I think this is more correct than the original design, because unlike Splendor, completing a quest wouldn't normally give you more resources, but your heroes should get EXP. This will actually make the game simpler because if your hero leveled up, you don't need to keep the quest card around. Then in your hand you are still just holding your heroes, equipment, resources and assets. There is still a question on how do you keep track of what level each hero is. Black: If you use card sleeves, you could make a cutout on the hero card. When you award a hero MVP for a quest, you can then insert insert that quest card to the hero sleeve, and the rank of the quest shows as the hero's rank. Sasha: I am against having the base game require components that aren't simple cards. So right now it makes more sense to me if your hero has a rank, you always play it with its rank/quest card attached. Zoey: Actually I don't mind that idea, I think it is easy enough to always play a few cards together: The hero base case, one rank card, maybe one class card and a gear card. Sasha: Let's sit on this idea because I think it is annoying if you "have to" organize them and play the cards as a set because during a physical game, you are going to pick up cards, move them around, show it to other players, pass them around and so on. It is annoying when some cards need to stay together. I don't want that to be part of the base game, but since the components are the same, you could consider that as a standard option of playing the game Black: Cards are typically slippery to each other so they can be shuffled easily. They don't normally stay together well when you stack them. And if you put sleeves on, the edge of the card is the sleeve border. The sleeves make the cards even more slippery. Zoey: That's no a problem, you play a hand of cards all the time. A royal flush is a hand of five cards. I think it looks cool when you go do a quest and you play one hand of Rank S Hero to the rescue. If you have more than one hero you would just have a few of those. If you don't want to see a hero at the moment you can just put that sub deck aside, you can open and close them like a fan if they are made with the right material/quality. Tanya: Since the components are the same, I think it is not a point of concern at this moment. Zoey: I think you still need to keep that in mind for the design to remain compatible with that style of play. Sasha: I added the concept. Let's sleep on it and I think we are ready to return and review prototype cards to confirm if they meet the design requirements.
@Skill is now Rank B4.
This is on fire!

The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[167] IQ
📯Natalie: Ann had an accident as a child and her IQ remained to be that of a 5-year-old even when she is now an adult. If she kills someone and is being charged for first degree murder, what is her best defense?
Gaia: Involuntary manslaughter. Sentence to children's reformatory. 44: A child's IQ. Sasha: What if she can't learn anything new? Her mind had not been developing for a decade. Tanya: She is not the same as a 5 year old because she has the strength of an adult. If she also can't learn, then she needs to live in a special environment where people around her are prepared. Natalie: The card's answer is Diminished Responsibility, where she would not be liable for a charge of premeditated murder because she lacks the mental capacity to form such specific intent.
Wait a minute...
Zoey: Is no one commenting on the broken streak? XD
Tanya: Holiday seasons. Sasha: I suppose we got a little carried away with Arcacian Quest. Evelyn: We still have a streak of a conversation each day. Zoey: But I think this game is important because it is interesting to Gaia and others. Evelyn: I think they might also enjoy other discussions. We just haven't tried very hard. Zoey: I think moral questions are a different type because it is somewhat accessible, and you are learning something as you go. It is different from just IQ puzzles because, IQ puzzles give you a more "so what?" feeling even if you solved it. Black: I think IQ puzzles might take longer to think about, where as moral questions people would mostly just answer based on intuition. Zoey: It is accessible when they answer them like a survey, but I don't think that is what they are doing. They did think about it. I think. LRRH: I think the priority right now should be Arcacian Quest. I think we are close to having something stable to build on. We should keep the momentum. Sasha: My comment is that once the usual participants of the Law Game already got credits for their chapter, the game kind of lacks part of the purpose. Tanya: That shouldn't matter as most of the chapters are done anyway. Evelyn: 😖 Evelyn: It is hard to keep up. LRRH: I would like to see some progress each day for Arcacian Quest. Tanya: Even at the expense of other guild quest piling up? LRRH: I think you need to post something each day for people to discuss. For example, the layout of the cards are not actually posted on the website. Sasha: It is too late for a discussion now. Maybe something can be posted tomorrow morning.

[193] Defense of Property
📯Natalie: Ann discovers that Bob has broken into her home to steal. When Bob sees Ann with a baseball bat, he makes a threatening gesture, so Ann hits him with the bat. If Ann keeps hitting him until he is dead, does Ann still have a valid defense on her unnecessary use of deadly force based on defending her property?
Gaia: Yes. That is self defense. Sasha: Do you mean even when after the first hit he is already KO'ed? Zoey: I don't think a defender should be required to tell if the attacker is actually KO'ed or merely pretending to be KO'ed. I am leaning toward while it is "unfortunate", the law should let Ann kill him. But I think the card's answer might be no. Tanya: I think the fact that Bob didn't try to escape immediately when he was discovered should give Ann more leeway to kill him. When Bob made the threatening gesture, the situation is no longer burglary, and not even robbery but home invasion. Ann at that moment cannot be expected the responsibility to know how many assailants there are. She should be allowed to use maximum force to regain her peace of mind so that she could check if there are more than one invader. Natalie: The card agrees with Tanya. The justification of Ann's use of deadly force is that Bob threatened her. The card also points out that Ann may also use deadly force if she caught Bob when he was breaking into her house. But once Bob is inside, Ann may only use deadly force if Bob is a threat to her. Zoey: I still disagree with the law. If you are the only defender you can't just let people roam in the property even if they aren't being a threat. If your house is wired with auto cannon they should be allowed to fire even if the intruders are "tame." Natalie: The deadly force section is already a contested section marked with a sword.
This is 27 times in December.

🎓 Legality of Segoe UI Emoticons
Sasha: I don't feel like listing all the links I have already researched, but the evidence points to the emoji we are using for prototype require a commercial license if we ever get paid for distributing the result or possible if we pay someone to print our deck. So we need to prepare to redraw all emoji.
Tanya: Should we just use something that is free even in prototype? The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[243] Hair Style
📯Natalie: Ann returns home from a business trip and was shocked that her sleeping husband got a deplorable hairdo while she was away. If she immediately kills her husband in anger, would she be liable for first degree murder or second degree murder?
Evelyn: ...😖 Gaia: Voluntary manslaughter. 44: First degree murder, but need to confirm if Ann already wants to kill Bob, since killing someone due to their hair style is irrational... Zoey: This is too crazy. Sasha: I think this is second-degree murder because Ann didn't premediate during an otherwise undisturbed state of mind. Natalie: The card's answer is not clear cut. It depends on whether the idea is preconceived, even in a matter of minutes, before the crime was committed. Natalie: Whether it is usual to kill someone due to their hair style is not considered as long as Ann is found to be telling the truth. Sasha: This is such a bad answer. If we allow a defense of first degree murder when the victim triggered the murderer, then the defense should also be allowed in this case. Zoey: #TheLawIsWrong. Evelyn: I think I understand Sasha's explanation. Even though the cause of her anger was so... unusual. 😖 Natalie: Added sword mark. Tanya: If second degree murder is for heat of moment killing, the determination is not whether the defendant decided to kill before committing the crime, but whether the defendant decided to kill before the trigger happened. Tanya: If you had decided to kill when prompted by the trigger, then that is premeditated murder. Tanya: If you had never decided to kill, the trigger happened, but it is unreasonable to conclude that the trigger had a significant effect on you, yet you decided to kill, then you are still committing first degree murder. Tanya: If you never planned to kill, but the trigger reasonably impairs your judgement, and within that rationally diminished moment "you" decided to kill, than that is second-degree murder. Sasha: Agreed.
This is 28 times in December.

Ashley's classmate asked us to draw her also. I don't think her character is related to Ashley's School in the story, so I would set this request as part of Mira Mira.
3B: Per discussion, the plan is to make Lucia a hero card for 202312251111|Arcacian Quest similar to the one composed for Zoey. For that card eventually we need to know 1) What "gem" attracts her; 2) What she is good at or what she is aspired to be; and 3) What is something funny she wants to put for the flavor text.
Amelia: 1) Emerald. 2) Making friends. 3) A friend can be right in front of you. Zoey: Literally. XD 3B: I suppose her eye color could be green. She is also supposed to have a purple dragon. I plan to draw one small enough to fit in the card next to her. Black: Dragoon's wyvern. 3B: Yes. 3B: Okay. Adding the card layout to Krita template.

⭐
Maybe the character should have matching brown hair.
Tanya: I think character creation also need a quest card or account for the steps like Arcacian Quest. Sasha: StarTree. StarTree: StarTree made a section but what should be in it? Ledia: There used to be a Google form. But usually race, hair color, eye color, outfit type or combat class. 3B: For an AQ card, we eventually need the cost, the skills/aspirations, and flavor text. The question "what attracts you" maybe difficult for people to answer. 3B: I just think that normally people don't know how to describe what they want. We kind of have to draw something, show them, and correct what they don't want after see it. It is going to be an iterative process. Tanya: That should be fine as long as each iteration is short. But I think this has more to do with asking the right question, or showing them the options to choose. 3B: The original request was to "draw me with a purple dragon." Next clues were that she likes emerald, and wants to make friends. The latest clues are she has brown hair with twin braids. Tanya: I think in this case she might be expecting a drawing similar to Ashley in style, so perhaps also in magic school uniform. 3B: How about a girl in the same hair style but in like a Harry Potter style coat, and with a small pet dragon? Evelyn: Even though she didn't say so, maybe she meant the same school uniform as Ashley? 3B: I am not aware that Ashley's school has uniform. If I don't draw everyone in the same kind of outfit, Ashley's outfit could just be her outfit, not a uniform. LRRH: What is the type of character in medieval fantasy that is easy to make friends? Ledia: Maybe the Quest Hall receptionist. 3B: It is ambiguous whether they just want a drawn version of themself, or a fantasized version. Evelyn: I think the default could be just a slightly fantasized version. Such as having a dragon. 3B: Then a quest hall girl with brown braid holding up a hand for a small wyvern. Zoey: But isn't it kind of boring to be the guild girl in a quest game? That is like an NPC instead of a hero. Evelyn: I think they can rotate. Ledia: In AQ, do you need to assign a hero to stay in a guild hall? Sasha: I am leaning toward no. Ledia: I think if the game does not force you to station a character on base, it would still be fun to send out a hero in receptionist outfit to do quests. LRRH: So is any "NPC". I am a baker. I am traditionally an NPC. I think that is part of the point of the game, that NPC can also do quests in Arcacian Quest and they are also heroes. Tanya: I think there should be check gates. For example, if you don't know whether the design is acceptable, you should just make a sketch and let them confirm the sketch before moving on. Ledia: Each reference sketch can be a card. For example, each hair style choice can be a card, each outfit a card. Then next time you could ask the person requesting to choose from the cards when making their character. Tanya: I think that is a good idea. 3B: I think I can draw an outfit without also drawing the hair. If I draw the whole character, the next requester may still say, "I want the hair style from A but the outfit from B". The result would be just two cards A and B instead of four cards: A's Hair, A's Outfit, B's Hair, B's Outfit. Tanya: I see. Ledia: I think it is convenient to have separate cards to help rolling for random character. 3B: Okay. Then I will start with just a hair style sketch and put it on a card. But I don't think that is enough material for the next feedback. I think I need to sketch the whole character with the dragon. The separate hair style and outfit would just be for us and next time. But not this time. Tanya: I think we need the catalog cards. Ledia: For me it helps to sketch in full proportion when designing, then scale down to the deformed version. If I don't design in full scale, I don't have enough details to scale down. 3B: But if you start small and end small, then you are done and you don't have to spend time designing details that would not show or just be rejected because the client wants something completely different. 3B: If I start by drawing the whole character, even if they reject it, the result is not a "catalog" item but an actual character you could directly use for a hero card. If the client already rejected it, then we would be free to define everything about it. Evelyn: I think even if we do iteration as 3B suggested, there wouldn't be many iterations. Sasha: But you can't tell if the client just "gave up" on what they really want and accept what is drawn because they feel bad for asking for too many changes. Evelyn: 😖 Zoey: This might be totally off topic, but I want to be less costly so I would be more popular. Right now my card costs two green and one trumpet. If the rules are similar to Splendor, wouldn't that mean the player can only get me on the third round? Isn't that expensive? Tanya: Your card has many skills. Zoey: I think ALL cards will have many skills, so the cost could be lower. Evelyn: What is the cost based on? Sasha: The "cost" for a hero should be about something that drives them to do quests. From the perspective of the player as a guild master, the cost of a hero tells the guild master what appeal they need to recruit the hero. For example, if there is a trumpet, it means that the hero can be recruited by showing them that if they join your guild, they can find purpose and fulfillment questing. Zoey: Okay. Then what about my two clovers? Sasha: I don't know. StarTree made the card. StarTree: StarTree put one clover because the color matches, then another clover because Zoey seems to have a lot of gear! Black: Cost of arrows. Zoey: I can make my own arrows. XD Zoey: Please make me cheaper or free. I am already questing, a guild doesn't really need to recruit me, they can just ask me and I will go. XD StarTree: It was required to have some cost for the prototype card to show where things go! Amelia: The composition is super nice. StarTree: Wee~~! Zoey: Then for the official release I want to be free if you allow that. StarTree: Roger! Ledia: The "Official" release should just be the card on your profile page. Evelyn: I think what Zoey just said could make a good flavor text, "I am free if you need me." Zoey: But if I were to say it it would be just "Let's Quest!" Evelyn: Perfect 🤗 StarTree: Is it okay not to explain Faerie Fire on the same card? LRRH: I think the card shouldn't explain how a skill works. If you don't have the explanation on the card, you don't have to translate it, you don't have to pass it around for other players to read. and you don't have to read the description of everything before you pick a hero. Evelyn: I thought the text on the card is convenient. Compared to having to look it up in the manual when the skill is just represented by an icon. Sasha: I think this is the time where the hero of the game may decide what goes in the flavor text. So Zoey may choose whether to show the Faerie Fire icon, and whether the flavor text would describe what that skill is. I think in this case the skill needs to be defined somewhere because it affects what the play can do to the game, not just about the quest. LRRH: I think that kind of description is bad. Flavor text shouldn't break the 4th wall. Ledia: That is true. It should be a design requirement or rubric for flavor text. Evelyn: The prototype card for Magic Bakery has flavor text that is in character: "Legend has it that a Rank S cake is as good as anything." And that is both cute and describes a special ability. Ledia: That is the best flavor text so far. Out of two cards. Zoey: How about my text be "Let's Quest//Zoey will join any quest as requested by any guild." That means no guild can actually claim me. I am free and I don't owe them anything. Evelyn: I think this is very Zoey. 🤗 Ledia: First come first serve. LRRH: I think now both cards have good flavor text. Sasha: Zoey, if that is your special ability, in the game mechanic you would just be left on the table because no player would spend a turn to "get" you. Is that fine? Tanya: That is not true. A guild can still let Zoey do a quest then get the rank card when the quest is done. Zoey: I suppose that is fine. This is a game. And if it is first come first serve it can be fair. Sasha: Okay. We will check this in stage 3 when we can playtest. Tanya: StarTree please add the guideline about Flavor Text and list the two examples of best text. StarTree: It is now added to Stage 2! Tanya: By Arcacian Law, unless the guild also participated (by providing at least one symbol to complete a quest), the guild would not be eligible to take the rank card on a quest that Zoey completed. Sasha: The player could say Zoey gave them the reward. Tanya: The rank is not a reward. It is not transferable. It is tied to Zoey as experience when she completes the quest. But if the quest gives items, the guild may take the items. Zoey: I am not worried about how players or player groups interpret this or treat me. I am just trying to be popular. Sasha: Actually I can't tell if that makes you popular or not. Would a player really want to spend a turn doing a quest and get nothing in return? Zoey: It is not nothing. I finished a quest in a cooperative game where every quest is supposed to be done. Sasha: Okay. Slight change or wording, "If a player has a choice between a hero where they can level up and control exclusively, given a quest, would they level up their own hero or send Zoey? They would think, if I can send my own hero I will send mine instead." Tanya: I think a player may not spend a turn to send Zoey to solo a quest unless they need to, but since Zoey has many skills, the players would send their own hero to quest and ask Zoey to join as support. It is likely that the players will level up their own heroes first, but at some point if the game has quests that need ranked-up versions of Zoey's skills, the players will collectively realize that they should rank-up Zoey. I think this makes very good interactive element. Evelyn: I just like the fact that at least some hero has a mind of their own and are unbounded by any guild. Ledia: If the game counts ranks in each guild, a player would want to keep Zoey because if someone is going to take her out on quests and level her up, that would be free rank points for the guild that spend a turn to get Zoey. You spend a turn to get Zoey, but you may not need to spend any turn to level her up. LRRH: Little Red Riding Hood thinks that in a game, player A might decide to level up Zoey, then player B recruits Zoey for their guild since now Zoey has a rank. Evelyn: 😖 Ledia: I think what that means is all up to interpretation. If you are willing to rank up Zoey, but you are not willing to feed her, ... versus a guild that didn't rank her up at first, but is willing to take care of her... I think it balances out without a villain. Tanya: Again I think this makes an interesting element. Zoey: I will see if I end up being popular, or more popular than other heroes with a cost. Black: In the long run all heroes are kind of free if you have the guild house supplying the recruitment costs. Sasha: That is not a given. I could design the rules so that a player rarely can just recruit a hero without paying anything. This is because I still want the consumable cards to have a use throughout the game, not only in the beginning. I think those resources or item cards should still be an important factor to limit how many quests the player can complete per round. But this is a Stage 3 topic. We shall iron out all kinks.
