{"name":"Tanya","score":"15"}, {"name":"Sasha","score":"9"}, {"name":"Zoey","score":"8"}, {"name":"Vivi","score":"7"}, {"name":"Sylvia","score":"7"}, {"name":"Natalie","score":"6"}, {"name":"Arcacia","score":"5"}, {"name":"LRRH","score":"5"}, {"name":"Albatross","score":"4"}, {"name":"Patricia","score":"4"}, {"name":"3B","score":"4"}, {"name":"Kisaragi","score":"2"}, {"name":"Casey","score":"2"}, {"name":"Ledia","score":"2"}, {"name":"Fina","score":"1"}, {"name":"V","score":"1"}, {"name":"Ivy","score":"1"}, {"name":"P4","score":"1"} ]}
⭐
Should the guild adopt the same ranking as Arcacian Quest?
🔮 Quest Ranking
🔮Tanya: For Arcacian Quest, the quest rank is based on how much hostility the peacemaker is able to overcome to spread peace. Should we use the same scale on our own Quest Board?
Tanya: If we use the same scale, almost all of our activities would be Ranks D, C, B. But switching could direct our attention on how to complete Rank A and S. LRRH: I think it is against guild policy to say, "Rank S needs to mean such and such". But you are welcome to rank your own chapter that way and others may adopt your same ranking. Tanya: @Dungeon will switch to that scale. Evelyn: Does it mean adding a new node would no longer be an A? Tanya: In that scale, it doesn't matter whether you add a node or just add to the same node. It is about how well your content would work against hostility. Evelyn: If I add a tip on happiness without knowing who might read it, what rank would that be? Tanya: It depends on how well your writing could convince someone against happiness to be happy. Evelyn: I think I understand. If I write them as reminders, without assuming that the viewer is seeking or avoiding happiness, then it would be Rank B (targeted to a neutral audience). Is that correct? If so, there is not much of a change except it is harder to get Rank A or Rank S. Tanya: That is correct. Sasha: Then what is Rank D? I thought training is Rank D. Tanya: Training yourself is Rank D. Reporting for others to learn is at least Rank C. Black: You mean Rank C is a node that would work on a viewer who already has a bias to like the subject, but not on a viewer who has no bias to like the subject. What exactly is a Rank C node? Tanya: I think it would include nodes with too much assumptions and jargons, or nodes that use language that would turn off a general audience. Zoey: So if you address the viewer as a "peacemaker", would that be presumptuous and a turn off? Or would that be an effective rapport and make the node Rank B? Tanya: The effect of that should make the node Rank B, or even Rank A or S. Sasha: That is reverse bias. Appeal to Common Decency. I think that skill by itself is Rank A. {"cmd":"url","url":"https://freakonomics.com/podcast/enough-with-the-slippery-slopes/","desc":"🔗"} Zoey: If that language makes an addition Rank A, would it be too easy? Tanya: I think that level of peacemaking should be accessible. Zoey: I meant, if we make a knowledge card with the concept of Appeal to Common Decency, would the player hero become Rank A in that skill as soon as they draw it? Tanya: Knowing it doesn't mean that you would use it. I think when you use it your message still need to be morally sound. Zoey: Technically peacemaking doesn't mean that you know the correct solution. It could just mean that you de-escalated a conflict so the participants can reach a solution. Tanya: Then I agree that it could be a common skill for Rank A quests. Sasha: If the player heroes can do Rank A quest since the first month, there would be no sense of leveling up. The game would feel tedious continuing for 12 months. Tanya: I don't think that would be the only or even relevant skill in many quests. Evelyn: I think it is strange if we know useful skills but don't teach them from the start. The skill itself should be a freebie. Tanya: Yes. I think it is worthy as a basic card Black: I want to point out that "Appeal to Common Decency" is not a logical fallacy when it is not being used to assert what is true, but as an assumption of or a plead to the viewer's intent. It is the similar to "innocent until proven guilty." Unless they have said they are not trying to make peace, you assume that they acted thinking that they are trying to make peace. Then you address whether their action helps or obstruct that presumed goal. LRRH: StarTree could you make a node for this? StarTree: What should this skill be called? Zoey: Presumed Goodness? Tanya: If this is called Presumed Goodness and is Rank A, then Assertive Goodwill is Rank S. Sasha: Okay. The game will totally break if the player can just get basic Rank S cards. If that is a basic card, it should be unranked, so the player still need to use it to do quests and level up through completing quests. Zoey: I think the card should be fair and reflect the actual rank of the skill. The fact that it doesn't solve all problems just means the problem has more costs. Black: Is a quest rank card applicable to any skill? If so, just having the skill be Rank S by itself would not make all other skills Rank S. Sasha: But this skill is so simple and basic, would it be a basic healing skill? Tanya: I think part of the game should be about the fact that one hero cannot do all the quests. So even if your hero gets that free Rank S skill card, it is not the end of the game because the other heroes don't have that card, and you can't rely on one hero to finish all quests. Black: If the deck is thick, you might not even draw that card. Sasha: StarTree please make the node and the card. StarTree: Roger!
@Arena is now Rank C2.
StarTree: StarTree thinks that the wording is difficult to understand, therefore, even though the skill itself is Rank S, the node is Rank C! Tanya: I see.
Wee~~!
{"type":"chat","id":"202401072233","parentid":"202312251111","parentname":"Arcacian Quest","icon":"🔮","title":"Design Session","prev":"202401062040","author":"Tanya","location":"Game Room"}
{"cmd":"daisy2","issues":"11","quests":"1092","activities":[ {"ch":"20","rank":"A","updates":"1","last":"20240101"}, {"ch":"24","rank":"B","updates":"2","last":"20240102"}, {"ch":"30","rank":"B","updates":"2","last":"20240102"}, {"ch":"17","rank":"A","updates":"3","last":"20240102"}, {"ch":"16","rank":"B","updates":"3","last":"20240102"}, {"ch":"28","rank":"S","updates":"1","last":"20240107"}, {"ch":"31","rank":"B","updates":"1","last":"20240107"}, {"ch":"23","rank":"C","updates":"2","last":"20240108"} ],"players":"Black, Evelyn, LRRH, Sasha, StarTree, Tanya, Zoey","merits":"Tanya","recognitions":"","kudos":"Black, Evelyn, LRRH, Sasha, StarTree, Tanya, Zoey","awards":"Arcacia, Black, Evelyn, Ivy, Natalie, Sasha","top":[ {"name":"StarTree","score":"33"}, {"name":"Black","score":"16"}, {"name":"Tanya","score":"15"}, {"name":"Sasha","score":"10"}, {"name":"Natalie","score":"9"}, {"name":"Evelyn","score":"9"}, {"name":"Arcacia","score":"6"}, {"name":"LRRH","score":"6"}, {"name":"Zoey","score":"6"}, {"name":"Ivy","score":"5"}, {"name":"Kisaragi","score":"4"}, {"name":"Ledia","score":"2"}, {"name":"Fina","score":"1"}, {"name":"James","score":"1"}, {"name":"V","score":"1"}, {"name":"Casey","score":"1"}, {"name":"Vivi","score":"1"}, {"name":"Sylvia","score":"1"}, {"name":"P4","score":"1"} ]}
Assertive Goodwill is a Cooperative Peacemaking Paradigm tactic that allows progress to be made even if one (or all) party is suspected of wrongdoing or acting with evil or hostile intentions. At the pinnacle of this tactic, you could have multiple evil masterminds each plotting for world domination, but end up saving the world in their combined evil efforts. Black: Assertive Goodwill is done by carefully presume the good intention of others to allow the option to do good without making oneself vulnerable.
Example 1: Hacking
A hacker hacks for fun. Instead of persecuting them out of fear of their capability, you invite willing hackers to be isolated to help your society discover its own vulnerability before actual hackers try to hack you for real damage.

Key Takeaway

  1. The tactic user did not commit to any deceptive act. The hacker knows the reason they are isolated and agrees to do so. They did not round up every hacker. There is a job description and willing hackers applied.
  2. The tactic user may require isolation regardless of whether they believe the hacker is at risk of using their skill to harm society. This makes the tactic user neither naive nor prejudiced.
  3. The path they take helps catch other evil-doers or prevent evil from happening (such as when you now have the only person in the entire world that could hack like that and he is helping you trying to defend from a hacker better than him which in reality does not exist.)
Example 2: Bomb Threat
Ann has a legitimate request that is being ignored. A bomb threat happens regarding that request. Bob suspects that Ann committed that bomb threat, and argues that her request should not be heard. However, by hearing her request (which in this case is overdue), the bomb threat with such a motive would be defeated.

Key Takeaway

  1. While it is true that the bomb threat got people's attention to the issue, the request itself is already a part of a harmless process, therefore no additional restriction or confinement needs to be based on Ann for the hearing.
  2. The use of assertive goodwill in this protects the society from being suspected of being prejudiced against Ann.
  3. The system can still be looking for the bomb threat maker regardless of whether it agrees with the hearing, and agreeing with the hearing does not stop the system from treating Ann as a suspect. The status of Ann being a suspect does not disqualify her from the hearing.
  4. If Ann was not the one making the bomb threat, by using assertive goodwill, the society would prevent itself from exercising further injustice to Ann. Society is not giving up on investigating the bomb threat and has no reason to take the risk of treating Ann with prejudice.
Example 3: Presumed Peacemaker
Unless a party has said they are not trying to make peace, assume that they acted with the intention to make peace. Then address whether their action helps or obstruct that presumed goal.

Key Takeaway

  1. This skill is similar to the concept of "innocent until proven guilty", but takes a step further conceptually that the tactic user is not even trying to judge whether the other party is guilty, but to channel the effort into a better overall outcome.
Example 4: Not monsters, but heroes
Early in the design of Arcacian Quest, monster hunting was part of the quests, but we moved away from that concept because in Arcacianism, people are not monsters, but peacemakers of different rank. For example a peacemaker who only cares about their own peace would be rank 6 (conquest). It is not know whether they could change into better peacemakers.

Key Takeaway

  1. In one way of applying this skill, it breaks down the we versus them argument, and puts everyone on the same scale of peacemaking, where everyone is supposed to try and help each other level up in peacemaking.
Assertive Goodwill
Rank S Skill
 {"id":"202401080043","parentid":"202207161423","parentname":"Philosophies","icon":"☀️","title":"Assertive Goodwill","subtitle":"Rank S Skill","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2018/02/03/15/40/landscape-3127859_1280.jpg","music":"","author":"Black","description":"","card-text":""}
⭐
This is StarTree making a card. Wee~~!
StarTree: Making icon. Layout and tweaking... Sasha: I think it would look better without "Rank B", "Cost" and the QR code. StarTree: Done! Evelyn: I like how this is an item. Tanya: The text isn't clear what assertive goodwill is. Black: Maybe "without coming loose" should be "without letting loose." LRRH: Could we somehow indicate that the number in the bottom is a node ID? Sasha: But that number is also a timestamp. I think the player would just learn the usage of the number elsewhere, such as on a different card with the QR code. I don't think every card, or even any of them need a QR code. I think it looks ugly with it. Black: I think the card does not need the herald skill as a requirement. LRRH: Instead of using a heart as ingredient, should it be a ball of Yarn? Tanya: But conceptually you don't need threads to use assertive goodwill. LRRH: Yarn symbolizes the connection between people. And the thread card is a heart card anyway. Tanya: I see. Evelyn: Could it have both the heart and the yarn? Black: I think it doesn't need the heart. You can be a psychopath and use assertive goodwill. StarTree: Making a red version of the yarn ball. Done! LRRH: Could you add some background shine for the item? StarTree: Done! Sasha: I think the item should be a discard item because the wording means it is an item you give to someone else. LRRH: I think you can wear it yourself. Ledia: i think it is more fitting if it is a give-away item. If you use it to complete a Rank S quest with a heart, then you get the permanent Rank S heart. Sasha: Yes, exactly. StarTree: Done!
@Wish is now Rank B3.

The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[278] Puppet
📯Natalie: Ann fires a shot into Bob's house to kill Bob, but the bullet only hit his decoy. Angry Bob rushes out to pursue Ann. If Bob kills Ann right there, is that murder or voluntary manslaughter?
Gaia: Voluntary manslaughter 44: It is voluntary manslaughter, since it was not pre-meditated. Fina: It could qualify as self-defense because Ann tried to kill Bob. In reciprocative justice. Natalie: The answer is voluntary manslaughter. There is objectively adequate provocation, Bob was subjectively provoked, and there was no time to cool off. And as we know this would not qualify as self-defense in normal law.
@Arena is now Rank B3. This is the second game in 2024!

🔔
The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[298] Deadly Weapon
📯Natalie: Ann points a real gun at Bob, saying she would fire at him. Ann knows that the gun was not loaded, but Bob does not. Is Ann guilty of assault with a deadly weapon?
44: Yes, since that is real gun and she said she would fire it. Gaia: Ann is guilty of making a threat. LRRH: I think regardless whether the gun is loaded, Ann's crime is threat... But the notes say Assault includes physical threat... So this is aggravated assault. Natalie: The answer is No, because an unloaded gun is not a deadly weapon unless it is being used as a club. Ann is guilty of ordinary assault Zoey: If assault is about creation of fear, it should be more about what the victim sees or what the defendant tried to convince the victim to believe. In this case the gun being no loaded reduced Ann's crime for no reason. Natalie: If Ann has bullets, she could have chosen to make the threat with a loaded gun. Should the crime be the same for 1) Ann who made a threat knowing that the gun is not loaded; and 2) Ann who knew the gun is loaded and still pointed at Bob and made the threat. LRRH: The second Ann does seem more dangerous, even the situations are the same from Bob's perspective. Zoey: I am saying there should be three levels: Ann with just her fist, Ann with an unloaded gun pretending that it is loaded, and Ann with a loaded gun. For the threat part of the crime, 2 and 3 should be the same because they are the same from Bob's perspective. For 3, you could add a crime to Ann for reckless handling of a firearm (for pointing a loaded gun at someone). Ann would be guilty for the reckless handling regardless whether she was trying to make a threat. Zoey: Then you get your result: that the over sentence is worse if Ann knowingly threatened someone with a loaded gun. And I also get my result: that using an unloaded gun to make a threat is not the same as making the threat barehanded. LRRH: To me the part that doesn't make sense is, why is point a gun at someone "assault"? I think the defendant would at least have pulled the trigger to qualify. If they hadn't pulled the trigger, there is no physical attack made. Fina: If you haven't rolled for hit/miss, you haven't assaulted anyone. Fina: If the gun is not loaded and the defendant knew it, the defendant cannot be charged with assault unless they are hitting people with the gun itself. Fina: But if they didn't know it was not loaded and pulled the trigger, that counts as assault. Tanya: Sword mark please. Natalie: Marked and added some explanation.
@Seed is now Rank B3. This is the third in 2024!
{"type":"chat","id":"202401102007","parentid":"202301011739","parentname":"Law Game","icon":"⚖️","title":"Law Game 102","prev":"202401092227","author":"Natalie","location":"Paladin Hall"}
⭐
I think we need a to standardize the card layout.
🎓 Standard Layout
Black: I know this is a highly debatable subject, but I think we need some guideline on where things should be, or at least a better summary of what we learned so far about the card layout.
Black: In the beginning, the card layout resembled a MTG card where the cost is on the upper right corner. Black: While that made the cards look decent, those icons are too small when the card is laid on the table. Black: In retrospect, this difference happens because in MTG, you read the cost up-close when the card is in your hand. But in our game, you need to read the cost while the card is on the table. You don't need to read it while the card is already yours. Black: Therefore, for our design, a general guideline should be the cost is at near the bottom of the card. The rest of the card is for what the card offers. Black: StarTree please make a review slide. StarTree: Roger! StarTree: Outlining. Tweaking. Making Icons. Remaking cards for overall layout review.
Wee~~!

StarTree is making Archive 3 with a start date of 2023 Dec 25 so that the Arcacian Quest design node is in the new archive!
Zoey: Special Treatment XD StarTree: StarTree makes a backup. Wee~~! Ivy: Shouldn't you just use a cache section? StarTree: To do so will require either one more click or to use JQ! StarTree: Changed codes for Archive 3. LRRH: I think this is fine, the cutoff dates don't have to be exactly at the start of a year. Ivy: But who is going to remember the dates? LRRH: Why do you need to remember it? Ivy: You are right. It is none of my business. Black: When a node is loaded, is there a way to show which archive it is from? StarTree: It is possible in the GitHub code! Black: I think we can add that code if we really need to know that. StarTree: Adding function ArchiveNumSelect. Modifying PIN2 macro decode. Done! The Node ID clipboard now shows the archive number in the hints. Zoey: StarTree is unstoppable. XD Ivy: Thank you. StarTree: Wee~~!
@Board is now Rank B4.
Vivi: Could we talk about the card layout? Sasha: We could talk about the card layout but I don't want people to be too attached to the layout. As long as the gameplay is not said and done, the layout can change a lot. LRRH: If the game is not too different from Splendor then we know what needs to be on the card. Sasha: Okay. New section.
❤️ Card Layout Discussion
Sasha: Despite my warning, this is a section for discussing the card layout. Please be warned that the layout may change drastically depending on what we decide for the gameplay.
Black: What do we need to confirm about the gameplay to move forward? Don't you need cards for playtest? Sasha: That is debatable, but I don't think you need to know what a card looks like for a large part of a gameplay play test. Sasha: Just use your imagination that the card is designed and has a layout. Black: Then what do we need to have a playtest? Sasha: Let's start with the pitch.
🔮 Gameplay Pitch
Sasha: A gameplay pitch is a very short description of what the game is about. Here we are creating and refining the pitch based on what we want to do from the vision survey.
Sasha: In Arcacian Quest, the players cooperate as guild masters to recruit heroes and upgrading their guild halls to complete as many quests as they can in the course of a year. The center of the play area are quests and resources they could try to get by sending their heroes. But beware, quests can get complicated and may not be as straight forward as they seem. Sasha: Does this sound interesting? Evelyn: I think it sounds interesting. LRRH: Yes it sounds interesting. Sasha: The next one is Zoey's idea if I were to make a pitch for comparison. Sasha: In Arcacian Quest, the players cooperate heroes learning skills and upgrading their gear to complete as many quests as they can in the course of a year. The center of the play area are quests and resources they could try to get. But beware, quests can get complicated and may not be as straight forward as they seem. Sasha: Is this more or less interesting? Zoey: I think my idea sounds more interesting. XD If you play as a guild master your attention would be spread across different heroes. That means each hero may only get or do a few things and the game ends. Tanya: I think the guild master version is more interesting because if the game has only 3 players, it means only those three heroes would be completing all quests, which could get boring and unrealistic. Sasha: StarTree please add a section with the pitches and main comments. StarTree: Roger! Evelyn: I like the recruiting aspect of the first idea. I think to recruit someone, you need to give them what they want. I like that part of the game. Zoey: In my idea you can still have other hero cards with wishes. You can still "recruit" them by helping them. You just don't play them as heroes. XD Evelyn: I think the guild master version seems more flexible because the player could choose to play as a guild master or as just one hero, then both types of players may play together. Zoey: Fair enough. Sasha: Before I start asking for a vote, let also see this third design, which is actually from Evelyn. Evelyn: I did? 😅 Sasha: In Arcacian Quest, the players cooperate as guild masters to recruit heroes and build their shared town while completing as many quests as they can in one year. The center of the play area is the modularly expanding town that benefits all everyone. The guild masters earn honor by providing the best amenities for everyone, and by completing quests. But beware, quests can get complicated and may not be as straight forward as they seem. Tanya: This. Sasha: What do you think? Should the center of the play area be the quest board, or the town map? That is a huge difference in what components are needed. LRRH: I think it would be cuter if the center is the town. It would probably map better if we want to mirror reality. Black: The components might not need to change. you are just rearranging where the cards would be. Zoey: When you upgrade place, do you just put the upgraded card on top? Sasha: Something like that, I have some ideas. But let's focus on which one sounds the most interesting or worthwhile to continue? Evelyn: I think the town version would be more relaxing because center piece is not what the players need to do, but what they have already done, together. I could imagine when the game ends well the players would want to take a picture of the result. Tanya: I think the third idea has a lot of potentials especially when there are many variables we have not discussed. It could also be the most complicated of the three. Is there merit in considering designing for Zoey's version first, then Sasha's, then Evelyn's? Black: There might be something fundamentally different about the cards if the game is about town building. I think most likely the build cards need to be double sided. Tanya: I think they can be one-sided because the cost icons and what the location provides can be the same. Sasha: Okay. Please say which idea you like the most and include one short reason or comment.
LRRH: I think town building has the potential to be the cutest, but it takes the most art, so it would be the most expensive design. Tanya: Are we judging based on what we want to see completed the most, or what we should focus on next? Sasha: What you want to see completed the most, assuming if it could be magically done tomorrow. Evelyn: I like this concept more because the center area is not what the players still need to do but what they have completed together. Tanya: I think town building has the most potential for the player to see parallels to real life, and thus have the most "live game" possibilities. Black: If we can pull off the town-building game, the result would be quite unrecognizable compare to Splendor. But I don't think we can complete this. It just takes too much art work.
Sasha: I think that needs a new section.
❤️ Town Map Prototype
Black: What do you imagine the town map would look like? Is it a bird's eye view? Does it show isometric buildings? Does it just show a scenic picture of the location?
LRRH: I think it should be bird's eye view. If it just show scenes it would look like forbidden island. I don't think that is particularly cute. Evelyn: I think the style in Adventure Begins looks cute. Evelyn: I've just realized how hard it is to do what I am expecting. 😖 Sasha: For gameplay testing, we don't need any actual graphics. Black: Sticking with the same 3.5 x 2.5 size card, I think the map tile portion can take the top square, and the bottom could be the cost to enable the card's icon. Black: To place a tile card to the center, the player either place it completely next to a card, or in a way that covers the cost of an existing card, if the cost is covered by other active icons on the map, of if they paid enough icons. Tanya: StarTree please make a review slide. StarTree: Roger! StarTree: Making new template. Making icons Tanya: I think the rule for harvesting should be having no adjacent vacant slot. Without this rule, the players would want to build a long town instead of a compact town. Black: I think that would result in too many unproductive tiles. Maybe the rule could be, when you lay down a tile, the cost portion may cover another tile's cost, making it cheaper to complete the tile underneath.
Wee~~!

💟 Dream Symbols
Events and objects in dreams sometimes have symbolizes the same thing for different people in the same or different culture. What do you often see in dreams? What do they mean to you?
🧵 Threads
Black: 2023-11-14: I dreamed of pulling threads out of my finger. It was an odd dream so I looked up what it might mean. One explanation that seemed to be what I was feeling was that I needed to untangle myself from a bad relationship. {"cmd":"url","url":"https://behappyhuman.com/dreaming-about-thread-meanings/","desc":"🔗"}
🔔 Dream Signs
Dream signs are things you can see or experience in a dream that you could make yourself to be aware of to tell they you are in a dream. What are your dream signs?
❤️ Sleep Cycle
A complete sleep cycle is about 90 minutes: 65 minutes of non-REM sleep, 20 minutes of REM sleep (dreaming), and 5 minutes of non-REM sleep. The REM sleep phases are shorter during earlier cycles and longer during later ones.{"cmd":"url","url":"https://fmidr.com/the-power-of-the-sleep-cycle/","desc":"🔗"}
Dreaming

This is Tanya trying to organize the list of card ideas.
🔮 Card Ideas
Tanya: The card ideas section has too many unsorted ideas. We should score and rank them.
Tanya: StarTree please score the unscored. StarTree: Roger! Ivy: Why aren't you using Guild Log for this kind of scoring? Then you don't have to count. StarTree: Should card ideas be logged as incomplete until the card is made and has a node? Ivy: Yes... Right now you can't even easily sort them. StarTree: StarTree is doing it wrong. 😭 Sasha: I wanted people to be able to see the card ideas easily so they don't post duplicates. Tanya: I think there shouldn't be that many categories. It might be fine once they are sorted. Tanya: StarTree please make a section for Seasonal Cards. StarTree: Done! Tanya: Adding descriptions to Add-on, Common, quests with penalty, skill cards, Guild cards, hero cards, Items, Monster, Place, Acting. Sorting Tanya: I think it is now sufficiently sorted. Next we should prioritize which card types are the most important to consider. Sasha: StarTree please add Zoey and the border law cards on the list. I think we should be able to see the cards we already made. StarTree: Adding Zoey, Mira Mira, Border, Bad Weather, Assertive Goodwill, Arcacian Principle, Magic Bakery, Lucia, Leaderboard, Undead attack. Sasha: I think you can include the woodcutting area card. Black: Does it occur to you that a deck of place cards could be the entire game by itself? Tanya: True, but it is not clear what educational value that would be. Sasha: You would still need some kind of token to get started. Black: You could use the back side of the place card as the token. On a given turn, the player would place a card along with any cost not covered, or draw a card. Tanya: How do you score? Is the game still cooperative? Black: The score would be the total number of productive tiles. Sasha: I think it would be a functional game but quite boring. Zoey: The further you get from the heroes the more boring the game becomes. Black: Starting from the base town building game that "works", we can add the heroes. Each hero has skills, so if a guild master recruits the correct hero, they would save spending a turn drawing a tile card just to spend it as a wild resource. And I think the more heroes you have, the more actions your guild can do per turn. When you have two heroes, you can draw two cards per turn. Tanya: I like how the game "cannot" break in this design. Sasha: What stops the players from drawing the whole or most of the deck before starting to place tiles? Sasha: The issue won't be there if the players are competing. Black: Maybe each round the players must place at least one tile, or the tile deck will burn one card (that simulates a competing country had taken the opportunity). Tanya: Simple and functional. Zoey: So if I am in the game, how would I help the game? Black: You would still have the compass icon. I imagine that a number of tile cards (especially wilderness cards) would have the compass as part of the cost to continue. Zoey: Okay. I am sold. At least my character will be useful. Black: Since the game might not even need any text on the cards, sometimes the cost could be a dungeon. In that case Zoey can fight. Tanya: How do you keep track of individual player score? Black: I think you don't. If you really want to keep score you would need to do it separately or each player build their own town, put draft the tile cards from the same pile. Tanya: If the game can keep player scores then the game would have basic educational value for Arcacianism. If you build something beneficial to others, you are supposed to earn honor. Black: Let's ignore who keeps score, what actions are worth scoring? Tanya: I think the player should get a point when they help make a tile productive by closing a side of a productive tile. Sasha: This can be done fairly easily with paper and pencil.
Wee~~!

🔔
Let's do this. Black: Preparing the report.
[A1] Completing Quests On Time
📯Black: Last year, talked about TPK and that we made better time tracking and estimates and checklist. After that, we decided that we would track if we meet deadlines on quests at the field log.
Tanya: StarTree please complete the markings. StarTree: There were 3 misses out of 21. That makes it 85.7%, which is Rank B! StarTree: The three misses were Pisces, Swarm, and Ham Island. Tanya: I don't think we are responsible for Swarm. It already went down when we got involved. We were the rescue team. StarTree: Then it is 90% and Rank A! Tanya: What happened to Pisces and Ham Island? StarTree: Ham Island: There was confusion on who needs to do what. We though the island knows what to do, but they were waiting for us to do something. StarTree: Pisces: we received the crown quite late, did not schedule time to reenchant the crystal, and found an issue in the crown. We made the deadline, but later on found another issue that the crown could fall asleep if it was interrupted during spell casting. But that was an existing issue with the crown design. Tanya: It sounds like we made the deadline. StarTree: We did not make the original deadline, but another deadline set by another team that encountered other issues. Tanya: Could you track down the issue they had? I want to confirm what they were waiting on. StarTree: May 17: An issue with the crown was found, while a leak was fixed and tested. May 18: Testing by both teams. May 19: Tanya: I think they were waiting on us. StarTree: The original deadline was May 9, we received the crown on the 9th! Black: If there wasn't a leak, we would definitely be the team holding up. Tanya: We told the crown team when to deliver the crown, we adjusted based on when we need it, but there was only the minimum time for testing and fixing. Black: Compared to last year this was an improvement because we are now aware of a numerical count. StarTree: The retrospective count for last year was 15/19 = 78.9%. Rank B! Evelyn: I am not sure if improved because most of the quests this year are something we had done before. 😖 Black: Let's continue to the next topic. Maybe we will touch on that.
[A2] Instructions for Others
📯Black: Last year we talked about including the settings, instructions, and diagrams and making checklists. The after discussion said we will do ING / (ING+INB).
StarTree: There is no ING or INB tags! Tanya: We added ING and INB tags only last month. Black: Do we have a qualitative assessment? Evelyn: We started another checklist that is part of the binder. But it is mainly for us and not for another team... 😖 Tanya: We shared TSN on the shared board. That was new in 2023. Evelyn: We also added cross-check checklist on the shared board. Tanya: We also started making the manual, but that was not our initiative. Black: I think the cross-checking is for another section.
[A3] Internal Documentation
Black: Last year we said we kept notes at the shared board, and we kept the comments in the enchanting scroll. The after discussion said we would track DCG / (DCG + DCB).
Tanya: Those tags are also new from last month. StarTree: But there is one DCG from last month! Black: I think in this section we can talk about cross-check, so we are covered. Tanya: I think we can also mention the notes for each quest type as applied to different regions. It makes it easier to see how the same quest is different at different places.
[A4] Field Support
📯Black: Last year we only very briefly said that we supported. The after-discussion math is 1-(FLD FAIL / FLD Total).
StarTree: And that count is 1-(3/29) = 89.7%! Tanya: I don't think we keep track of that diligently. StarTree: Now tagging more FLD cases. StarTree: The count is now 1-(9/62) = 85.4%! Tanya: We need new tags FDG and FDB for this purpose. An entry could be marked FLD and Fail, but it doesn't mean our support was bad. Black: For the nine cases please check if it is FDG or FDB. StarTree: The count is now 59/62 = 95.2%! Black: Something new is that we are also keeping track of the 6 shield upgrade information.

📯Black: Last year we said we added to TSN, but not to the shared board. After discussion plan was %completed for training manuals upgrade.
Tanya: I don't think we worked on this so the percentage would be close to 0%. Sasha: This session is incredibly boring. Could we at least split this into two like last time? Black: Sure. Black: I think for this section we could reiterate what we did at the shared board. Black: Okay. I think this is done for today.

{"type":"chat","id":"202401131600","parentid":"202302050852","parentname":"Self Evaluation","icon":"📋","title":"2023 Review A","prev":"202312101940","author":"Black","location":"Whale Nursery"}
🔔
The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[342] Embezzlement
📯Natalie: Ann works at a vault. She wants to take a loan and needs collateral, so she told a gold bar from the vault as collateral, and later returned the gold bar after she had repaid the loan. Is she innocent of embezzlement?
Gaia: She is guilty even if she puts it back. 44: No, she is guilty the moment she told the gold bar. Zoey: I think if she did not intend to keep it for good, her crime is misappropriation, not embezzlement. I don't think it is a meaningful difference. Tanya: The crime should be less severe if the defendant planned to borrow, but without going to any legal protocol to do so. Natalie: The answer is NO. Embezzlement only requires the defendant to deal with a property in a manner inconsistent with the arrangement. What Ann would not be liable is larceny because she did not intend to permanently deprive the vault of the gold bars. Zoey: XD Zoey: That was me shooting myself. XD Zoey: I corrected some typos and moved a link to False Pretense in Embezzlement to False Pretense.
@Dungeon is now Rank B4. This is game 4 in 2024!
{"type":"chat","id":"202401131945","parentid":"202301011739","parentname":"Law Game","icon":"⚖️","title":"Law Game 104","prev":"202401121923","author":"Natalie","location":"Paladin Hall"}
⭐
Continue from yesterday to develop the town mode.
🔮 Keeping Score in Town Mode
Sasha: Yesterday Black pointed out that the town building mode can be a game by itself with just the tile cards. We ended with the question on how to keep scores in that case.
Sasha: First, the players could use any token, paper and pencil, or we could make a companion node to keep scores. But I think... Sasha: In the overall game, we could have the rule that when a player lays down a tile, they may draw one item card per tile edge it completes minues the edges it disturbs. When they do so, they keep the item card faced down as tokens, not as the actual item. Black: Can the player still draw item cards? Sasha: They cannot normally draw from the item deck. Each hero may explore, which means drawing a tile card. The player may draw from the hero deck only if tile card tells them to draw a hero. Tanya: Why can't the token card just be the back side of a tile card? There is a difference between a tile card that is kept facedown and a tile card in the player's hand. Black: I think that might be fine if the game simply ends when the common tile deck is empty, or enough cards are placed on the map. Black: When the tile deck is empty, a player would did more to build the town would have more "stock tiles" left. The score of that player is the number of stock tiles they have minus the number of tiles in their hand. Sasha: I think people might be confused which card is for what. If they are different cards, it is harder to cheat. A player can normally draw a tile card. If they cheat, the player who just draw one card every turn might appear to have the highest score even when they never built a thing. Black: The rule could have the score keeping pile near the draw deck instead of near the player. Tanya: If you use facedown item card as score tokens, wouldn't you have the same problem where the player may cheat and use token as an item? Black: A benefit of simply having honor token cards is that those cards could have different denominations. Then you can use fewer number of cards to represent a large count. Zoey: Among these ideas I like a browser scoreboard the most. There it can probably keep the history so everyone can verify. Sasha: On a 5x5 grid there are only a total of 40 points. Tanya: Or the game could just end when either the tile deck or the token deck is empty. Black: I think using tile cards as score cards is more elegant. Could the scoring simply be immune to a player just drawing a card each turn? Maybe every player may draw one card regardless, but the player may draw extra when they complete an edge? Tanya: If you use a tile card as a score card, when you place a tile you are losing a point. Even if you draw one bonus card, that only breaks even. Then there is no point to place a tile, not to mention you might be spending more tile cards as wild card to meet the cost. If the scorekeeping card is a separate thing, then you don't run into this problem. Black: Then I think the most elegant way is still using facedown tile cards as score cards. Zoey: I say it is the online scoreboard. XD Sasha: I don't think we are trying to design the standalone town building version. So is this discussion moot? I think the overall game should make the players want to place every tile card. Every tile card not placed should be a point deduction against the players. But we don't deduct points for items not drawn. So Items are a better choice to be used as score keeping tokens. We also deduct points for heroes not taken care of. So hero cards are not a good choice either. Tanya: The bigger the game gets, the less convenient it would be to use item cards as score tokens. Then score keeping could just be a separate module, the player may choose the way they want. Tanya: Keeping track of honor is one of the basic mechanics that makes a game appear Arcacian. The players are doing something good for the world and they are not being compensated. Honor is tracking that altruism. Sasha: Then should tile cards be made without assuming that there are hero cards or item cards? Tanya: I think it is okay as long as the card itself does not refer to heroes or items. Sasha: I thought of using the cost icon of tile card as a reward icon sometimes. For example, when you place a tile with a hut, it could have an icon of a person, meaning you may draw a hero card. Tanya: Your rule could just say each icon is a cost or ignore icons that are not costs. Black: Or get an extra point if it has a plus icon. Sasha: My question was, it is a good practice to even show such icon? Or should how to get heroes be completely separate rules? Black: Is there a general rule on whether there is a new hero at the tile? Sasha: If this is like an escape room game or an RPG, the bottom section would have a code specifying which hero can be found. Then the player could reveal specifically that hero. To make it modular, card doesn't specify, but could have an icon to draw a random hero. Black: I think it is too strange to draw a random hero unless that place is the plaza. If that place is tied to a specific hero, maybe just name the hero or say, "draw a ranger". Sasha: Okay, that is undecided. Tanya: I think we should proceed in steps. 1) Make only tile cards and play test. 2) Add hero cards and play test. 3) Add gear cards can playtest. 4) Add quest cards and play test. Sasha: I am moving the card sections in that order.
🍀 Cards for Town Builder Test
Sasha: 25 cards seems like a good number for playtest. The graphics on the card do not matter, but we need icon relevant to the place.. So. Let's go!
Tanya: I think we should have one card for each active chapter. Sasha: We have 26 chapters. Let's go. Tanya: Dungeon (Offer: ⚔️🎓| Cost: 🎃) Sasha: Magic Detective (Offer: 🔍| Cost: 🍮) Black: Harbor (Offer: ⚓| Cost: ⚔️🌳🎓) Zoey: XD Zoey: World Tree (Offer: 🌱🕊️|Cost: 📯⚖️🧭) StarTree: Vacation Island (Offer: 🥥|Cost: ⚓☀️) LRRH: Magic Bakery (Offer: 🍰🥨🍮🐣|Cost: ❤️❤️) Evelyn: Everkindergarden (Offer: ❤️💐|Cost: ❤️) Sasha: The offering of your place dosn't need to be used by another place. They could just be there for other things to be added later. James: Freedom Plaza (Offer: 🕊️📯|Cost: 🧹wheel, postsign) Natalie: Paladin Hall (Offer:🏛️⚖️|Cost:📯) StarTree: Park (Offer:🐿️🌸|Cost:🕰️🪑🧹) Cardinal: Deer Crossing (Offer:🦌|Cost:⚔️🎪🔮) Arcacia: Carrot Farm (Offer:🥕|Cost:❤️) P4: Ninja Village (Offer:🍃|Cost:⚔️) Zoey: XD Zoey: We are missing basic things like a hospital. XD Sasha: Okay, it doesn't matter who proposes it, we just need more places for playtest. Zoey: Hospital (Offer:❤️❤️|Cost:🎓🎓) Tanya: Library (Offer:📚|Cost:🎓🧹) Evelyn: Mira Mira (Offer:⚔️🦄|Cost:✂️🎀📯) Ivy: Adventurer's Hall (Offer:📯🎒|Cost:⚔️) StarTree: City Gate (Offer:⚔️|Cost:⚔️⚖️) Fina: Wilderness (Offer:🐻|Cost:🐾🧭🏕️) Skyle: Wheatfield (Offer:🌾🔮|Cost:🕊️) Black: Duck Pond (Offer:🦆🐤|Cost:🧹) LRRH: Townhouses (Offer:🏘️|Cost:⚔️⚖️🧹) LRRH: Wishing Tree (Offer:🎄|Cost:❤️) Casey: Reclamation Corp (Offer:🧱♻️🍀|Cost:🧹) Kisaragi: Market (Offer:🍎🥦|Cost:⚔️) Sylvia: Tavern|📯🍻|🌾🎻 Mikela: Academy (Offer:🎓🔮🧩|Cost:📚) 3B: Design Studio (Offer:🎀🎨|Cost:🎓❤️🍀) Sasha: It is now at 29 cards. Skyle: Plains (Offer:🌼🌻|Cost:) Skyle: I want to know what happens if a tile has no cost at all. Sasha: I think we can start playtesting.
🔮 Town Mode Playtest
📯Sasha: I am just going to list the starting rules if you want to make you prototype deck and playtest. Sasha: Your deck has 30 tile cards. The goal is to score as many points as you can until the deck is completely drawn. Sasha: You start with a shuffled deck, you take the first card and place it without cost on the play area. Sasha: Then, in each turn, you may draw a tile or place a tile if you can afford the cost. Sasha: You may discard a tile card in your hand for each cost icon you want to meet. Sasha: When you place a card, you get one point for each tile edge that is now complete. But subtract one point for each edge that becomes adjacent to the cost part of the card you are placing.
Tanya: If you just place them next to each other in one row, you get 29 points. Tanya: If you place them in two rows back to back, you get 43 points. Tanya: But the absolute max score you could get from 30 cards is 49. Sasha: What if you also get a point for each offered icon that you activate? An icon is activated if the title is not next to any cost. Tanya: If you can pay for it, can you place a card with the cost beneath an existing tile? Sasha: Yes. Tanya: Then in our deck the theoretical max score is 102 points. Sasha: I think that is fine. Casey: When you discard a card, where does it go? Sasha: They are gone from the game. Black: When you place a card in such a way that its cost would cover a cost of another card, what happens? Sasha: You cannot place a card that covers a cost unless you are paying for it as you place the card. Tanya: If there is no limit to how many cards a player may draw before placing any card, the player should draw all 30 cards then decide the best sequence to place them for maximum score. Sasha: I would consider that a win if it is not obvious what the actual max score is for this deck. Tanya: I think there should be a rule or mechanism preventing a player from first drawing the whole deck. Sasha: How about a max hand of five cards? But for the sake of testing you may also try having no hand limt. What strategy do you see?
@Freedom is now Rank S2.
Wee~~!

{"type":"chat","id":"202401141100","parentid":"202302050852","parentname":"Self Evaluation","icon":"📋","title":"2023 Review B","prev":"202401131600","author":"Black","location":"Whale Nursery"}
🔔
The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[379] Extortion
📯Natalie: Ann learns that Bob is cheating and says to him that she will tell his wife unless he pays for her weekly manicure. Is Ann guilty of extortion?
Gaia: Yes. 44: Yes. Natalie: That is correct! And it doesn't matter if Bob is really cheating. Sasha: Why exactly is this kind of behavior a crime? It is within Ann's freedom to tell Bob's wife? Why can't Ann profit from that information? Evelyn: Is it because Ann is hiding the truth from Bob's wife, so she becomes a conspirator? Sasha: But lying and cheating are not normally crimes. And Bob has no rights to tell Ann not to tell his wife. Sasha: Ann has a right to tell Bob's wife. Why can't Ann trade her right to do so for Bob's money? Tanya: Swords. Natalie: It is a point of discussion. {"cmd":"url","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blackmail","desc":"🔗"} Sasha: Well? I think we agree that if Ann is persuading someone to do something that would violate someone else's autonomy, then Ann is guilty for being a principal of such violation. But what if Ann is not trying to violate anyone else's autonomy through Bob? Evelyn: I think the blackmailer is violating the victim's autonomy. It is similar to price gouging. You are not supposed to increase the price of something just because someone needs it to survive. When you do that, the relation is not mutual help, not neutral, but exploitation. Sasha: That makes no sense. Suppose Bob learns that Ann knew about his cheating, and Ann would normally tell Bob's wife. If Bob offers to pay for her manicure in exchange of her not to tell, why isn't that mutual benefit? It doesn't matter who proposed. Evelyn: Would you use the same argument for price gouging? Sasha: I don't think that should be illegal. The person who chooses to price gouge is just at risk of being reciprocated. Tanya: I think price gouging could be illegal. If you normally sell an item, but you increase the price to someone who is dire, that price increase is not neutral. That is exploitation. Tanya: Exploitation is an attack to someone's autonomy. It is illegal to collaborate with "misfortune" help drive a victim to a worse situation. Exploitation not only helps drive the victim down, but also get benefit from doing so. Sasha: Suppose price gouging is exploitation, what is the case between Ann and Bob? Tanya: I think we should start by judging who is acting in malice. First we have Bob who cheated. He acted in malice by breaking an agreement with his wife. Next we have Ann who is now helping Bob conceal the truth from his wife. Ann's crime is that she put her honesty up for sale. Evelyn: I agree with Tanya. Tanya: Not all kinds of blackmail are the same. There might be some kind of blackmail that should be legal. Sasha: What is Bob has some fetish and Ann threatens to tell? Tanya: If Bob is simply self-conscious (that no one other than him would have minded), then Ann is guilty of acting in malice. She is trying to be rewarded for exploiting someone's weakness. Tanya: A person's autonomy does not include a right to exploit someone else's weakness. That is a Rank 3 concept. The law of a Rank 3 society would deem that illegal. Evelyn: I think I agree with Tanya. Natalie: Me too. Sasha: I can't find any weakpoint. Good job.
@Detective is now Rank A2. This is game 5 in 2024!
{"type":"chat","id":"202401142145","parentid":"202301011739","parentname":"Law Game","icon":"⚖️","title":"Law Game 105","prev":"202401131945","author":"Natalie","location":"Paladin Hall"}
{"cmd":"daisy2","issues":"10","quests":"1095","activities":[ {"ch":"17","rank":"A","updates":"3","last":"20240102"}, {"ch":"16","rank":"B","updates":"4","last":"20240102"}, {"ch":"7","rank":"B","updates":"1","last":"20240104"}, {"ch":"27","rank":"C","updates":"1","last":"20240104"}, {"ch":"13","rank":"B","updates":"3","last":"20240104"}, {"ch":"19","rank":"C","updates":"1","last":"20240104"}, {"ch":"26","rank":"B","updates":"1","last":"20240104"}, {"ch":"21","rank":"B","updates":"2","last":"20240105"}, {"ch":"29","rank":"A","updates":"2","last":"20240105"}, {"ch":"32","rank":"B","updates":"2","last":"20240105"}, {"ch":"12","rank":"D","updates":"1","last":"20240105"}, {"ch":"11","rank":"S","updates":"2","last":"20240106"}, {"ch":"25","rank":"B","updates":"4","last":"20240106"}, {"ch":"35","rank":"B","updates":"2","last":"20240106"}, {"ch":"15","rank":"B","updates":"3","last":"20240106"}, {"ch":"28","rank":"S","updates":"2","last":"20240107"}, {"ch":"23","rank":"B","updates":"3","last":"20240108"}, {"ch":"18","rank":"B","updates":"4","last":"20240109"}, {"ch":"24","rank":"B","updates":"2","last":"20240112"}, {"ch":"20","rank":"A","updates":"2","last":"20240112"}, {"ch":"30","rank":"B","updates":"4","last":"20240112"}, {"ch":"34","rank":"B","updates":"3","last":"20240112"}, {"ch":"33","rank":"C","updates":"2","last":"20240112"}, {"ch":"31","rank":"B","updates":"2","last":"20240112"}, {"ch":"14","rank":"B","updates":"4","last":"20240113"}, {"ch":"22","rank":"B","updates":"4","last":"20240113"} ],"players":"44, Black, Evelyn, Fina, Gaia, Ivy, Natalie, Sasha, StarTree, Tanya, Zoey","merits":"Black, Natalie","recognitions":"","kudos":"44, Black, Evelyn, Fina, Gaia, Ivy, Natalie, Sasha, StarTree, Tanya, Zoey","awards":"Arcacia, Black, Evelyn, LRRH, Patricia, Sasha, StarTree, Tanya","top":[ {"name":"Black","score":"23"}, {"name":"StarTree","score":"23"}, {"name":"Tanya","score":"13"}, {"name":"Sasha","score":"12"}, {"name":"Natalie","score":"9"}, {"name":"Evelyn","score":"8"}, {"name":"Arcacia","score":"6"}, {"name":"Kisaragi","score":"5"}, {"name":"LRRH","score":"5"}, {"name":"Patricia","score":"4"}, {"name":"44","score":"3"}, {"name":"Gaia","score":"3"}, {"name":"Fina","score":"3"}, {"name":"Ivy","score":"2"}, {"name":"Zoey","score":"2"}, {"name":"Ledia","score":"2"}, {"name":"James","score":"1"}, {"name":"V","score":"1"}, {"name":"Sylvia","score":"1"}, {"name":"P4","score":"1"} ]}
⭐
I feel I should help playtest because I was responsible for making that suggestion in the first place. Evelyn: But I don't understand what to do. 😖
🔮 Heuristics and Tile Relocation
Tanya: Last time Sasha asked if there are obvious player strategies on placing tiles. That depends on what happens to the tiles used as coin tokens.
Tanya: The normal number of points you could get by laying a tile (even if the tile does not become productive), is two points. This means that if you choose to discard a tile to make another tile productive, that change should earn you more than two points. Tanya: And, you don't want to discard a tile to activate a tile that you could activate without discarding a tile. That means the player needs to know the offerings and costs of the entire set if they want to do well. Tanya: Suppose the player knows that a tile's cost cannot be met by another active tile, then a basic check is whether the discarding tiles to activate a tile would at least pay for itself in that single placement. Tanya: So, if a tile costs one discard to activate, the tile being activated should have at least 3 offerings, or two to just breakeven (if you know the card you are sacrificing does not have an offering you want to activate). If it costs 2 discards to activate, the tile being activated should have at least 4 offerings to breakeven. This heuristic has not yet accounted for how much the activated tile could help activate other tiles. To me that depends on the icons on the tile. A player could discover this through experience. Evelyn: When I place a tile, if the cost is not met, may I place the new tile under the cost potion of another tile? Tanya: I assume you can't place a tile partially beneath another tile. And when you do that you don't get point for the adjacent edge. @Sasha? Sasha: May I know what you want to place beneath? Evelyn: It seems too stressful for the player to decide what they should put down, maybe the player should be allowed to place a tile based on where they want things to be, and worry about the costs later when they have seen other ties and know which one they should activate first. And there is a second question... Evelyn: If the player has a tile where the costs are already satisfied, can they place the tile by inserting the cost portion under an existing card. If that is allowed, a "complete" town would not have any cost portion showing. Sasha: Situation 2 is allowed. By default, you may also place a tile on top of an existing one, or have its cost portion cover the tile portion of another card. Doing so would deactivate that tile until the costs are met. I think consistency, Situation 1 is also allowed. You may place a tile with its own tile part under the unmet cost of another tile. Tanya: I don't think this would change the heuristic. Evelyn: Could you also add a tile between two, rotate or remove a tile? Tanya: Would that cost a turn or would that just be a free action as long as the players agree? Sasha: If the players agree they can do anything. But what is the reason behind those moves? Evelyn: Because if I get a tile that would look better I would want to make a change without starting the game over. 😖 Sasha: Should it be part of the game to make the player regret what they put because they don't know what other cards there are? In reality if the game starts with a town plaza tile, it is implied that there are other houses around even if you draw and place a forest tile next to the town. I don't think we should ask the player to withhold the forest card to first build out the town first before laying down the forest tile. Tanya: I think if the map is too malleable during play, it would lose some meaning that it is a town. Bad decisions are supposed to carry on and be costly to fix. Black: If this is a computer game, it would start with a geographical map, then you place the tile cards on the grid. You know how far things are when you place them. Sasha: But there is no way a forest the size of a town square and supply all the wood. So distance and size are symbolic. Tanya: I think it is okay if the map is meant to be topological. But if you insert a tile, what happens to other tiles in the same row where the cost portion become visible? Do all those tiles become inactive? if the map is truly topological, they should remain active because the player paid for them already. Sasha: Let's say the player have to pay for those costs again. It is somewhat a balance between "the player should plan ahead", "the player should not need to know what all the card are" and "the player should be allowed to make changes to the town." Sasha: The same with removing or rotating a tile. I want to allow such moves for aesthetic reason (and with a cost if that move causes any cost exposed. But I don't want to allow it for tactical advantage. I think the players can know the game's intent and judge in their case whether a change is allowed. Tanya: I think the game needs a guideline on what the map means and what is allowed by default rules. Insertion would cost one action because that is adding a tile. Conceptually swapping or rotating a tile should not cost an action, but you could get into a situation where the players are rotating a tile to select which adjacent tile to disable, or relocating an inactive tile elsewhere to minimize its impact on other tiles. Sasha: "Switching which neighbor to disturb" seems a clever mechanism, but relocating seems too much. If the map is topological, the default should allow insert but not remove or relocate. If you need to relocate a tile, that should correspond to a tear down and physically rebuilding the facility. The "costs" of the tile do not cover the cost of rebuilding. That cost is just whatever needed to make the tile participate in the alliance. It is in general assumed that the buildings already exist. Evelyn: That makes more sense that we are not building a whole town in one year. 😅 Tanya: But do you let players "swap out" a tile because it looks prettier, but the new tile as a cost that is met so the neighbors become active, then later on "insert" the original tile back when its costs can be met? Black: You mean, player A plays a hospital tile they can't fulfill, then later swap it out with a tile they can fulfill? Sasha: At least the hospital is never active, I think that should be allowed, if the other players agree. Tanya: If the other players need to agree on it, it means that the default rule is it is not allowed. Sasha: Um... No? I think in most cases placing any tile should require consensus. The players are playing cooperatively to simulate an Arcacian society. I don't think a player should just place a tile if another player doesn't want it to be place there. Tanya: Should Arcacianism allow some degree of autonomy? If each player has their share of autonomy, it could mean that when it is a player's turn, they may decide, by themself, where to place a tile and the other players have no rights to veto. A player could have the courtesy to ask first, but that should not be required. Fina: You can't just build and exercise your autonomy unless you have already claimed the zone as your optional zone. Sasha: There. Evelyn: It think if a player wants to have their own buildings they could start another map section that is disconnected from the other sections. Then in their turn they may build just on their own section, and other players may not disturb them. Sasha: I like that idea. It allows the players to decide who competitive they want to be on the fly. Tanya: In that case can common town sections also be disjoint? Technically you don't need to connect them until you need to activate a tile. Black: That would make the game layout easier. Then you don't have to specific which section are tiles that are just revealed, or which ones are "on the map". Sasha: What does Evelyn think? Of a disjoint common town map in the center? Evelyn: I think that should be up to the player. I think it would be convenient if the game does not require the tiles to connected. Sasha: It think that question is settled, although I think we don't nearly have enough tiles for that to really matter, because more than anything you should want a tile to become active, that means you need to connect it with something. Tanya: You could easily have four cards forming an activated but isolated set. If you don't require a new tile to be next to anything, you are minimizing the chance of collateral disruption. Sasha: I think that is fine because when you form disjoint places, you don't benefit from the offerings of other places. If you want to share the icons, you need to topologically connect them (and insert tiles in between if you need more space to expand in between). Tanya: Why do you penalize common sets that are disjoint? They are all common. Sasha: When they are disjoint, it implies that there is an obstacle among them. The things from one set cannot get to the other set. To resolve the obstacle, you would connect them at least topologically. If you have two complete rings, there is nothing stopping you from just placing them adjacent to each other unless there are some exposed costs. So being able to piece them together (at lease temporarily), shows that there is no obstacle. Tanya: If that is the rule, it means that normally there is no obstacle unless they can't fit together. Sasha: But in game design that is different because the players are not going to pay attention and check every time. Then the players might cheat, or having multiple disjoint sets "docking" to the single port. The tiles are not flying islands, so specify how they are placed so interesting situations may happen. The trade off to avoid those interesting situations is that the isolated set becomes isolated from the mutual aid. The game doesn't dictate what the players should do. The players may choose, but there are pros and cons represented by the possibility of collateral damage. Zoey: Can there be teleport crystals connecting disjoin sets? Sasha: Sure. Zoey: And when two disjoint sets have teleport crystals, they can support each other without sharing collaterals? Sasha: Yes. The teleport crystal is a card by itself. So you are choosing between just placing what would be the disjoint set just next to another set and connect them (for free), to spending something to activate the crystal tile. And if the crystal tile is "exposed" (having an edge without a tile), it could be "attacked" in some events. When the crystal is attacked the connection would sever. Tanya: The tradeoff seems reasonable. You need at least an island of 9 tiles to protect a crystal. But the entire deck only has 30 cards. Currently. Zoey: You are supposed to say, "just as planned." XD
Evelyn: Is there something else I can help? I think I need to see the cards for me to see more. Sasha: I think we are making good progress testing. StarTree please make a section and make cards. StarTree: Roger!
❤️ Tile Cards for Playtest
StarTree: How much details should be on the cards?
Evelyn: I want to see the cards with the offering icons and the cost icons. I want to know whether a player can tell them apart easily when the cards are tiled. StarTree: Roger! StarTree: Should these cards show landscape features such as pavement and rivers? Sasha: For now, no river, maybe except the Deer Crossing and wilderness cards. Sasha: And have pavement on at least one side for all other cards. StarTree: Roger! Sasha: The graphics (town layout) is not supposed to be part of "the game". The players are supposed to be allowed to customize the graphics and print their own card. So if a card is not oriented in a desirable way, it is not the intent of the game to make that a challenge. Zoey: Then does the player really need to draw a tile card from a deck? Or do they just select from a catalog and print the one they want? Sasha: They could just print them if they want. Tanya: Then the "deck" should be just open and face up. This allows each player to decide exactly how they want to build out the town. Zoey: If you let players just print cards from a catalog, wouldn't they just print cards with a lot of offerings and with cost they have already met? Sasha: There is a default training deck, and the players may customize their deck if they want to. Evelyn: I think if you have the tile deck face up, the players would pre-arrange the town before the first turn. Sasha: That's fine. There is still a game and discussion on what tiles to connect, what to discard. Tanya: Then the solo play is a puzzle, of "how would you arrange the tiles to get the maximum points, and what is the order of connecting them?" Zoey: I think in a real game the player will most likely disagree on which tile should be next to which. They probably won't build out the whole town before the game starts, but they might separate the tile cards in groups. Sasha: I think we don't need to tell them what to do. How they figure out what to do is part of the game and interaction. That is part of the training prompt. StarTree: Making slide, tile blue print, background, mock buildings, icon. A mock Freedom Plaza card is made! Evelyn: I think the offering icon needs a circle around it to distinguish them from the background. StarTree: Done! Evelyn: I think it looks better now, but the plaza itself is slightly too colorful. 😖 Sasha: Please make the roofs darker. StarTree: Done! Evelyn: I think the more subdued tile looks better. Sasha: I think it is too early to tell. StarTree please make 3 more town tiles. We need to see different tiles to really tell. StarTree: Roger! Zoey: I just like how the dove cannot be covered. It is an invincible dove XD Tanya: Is that correct? If a tile was previously activated, is the icon active as long as it is not covered? I thought every icon on a tile is inactive when any of its edges has disturbed. Sasha: But it does seem interesting if only the icon that is covered is disabled by collateral. Tanya: If that is the case I think we need a red border next to the tile to help show if a tile is even active. Zoey: What if the rule is that as long as an icon is not next to a cost bar, then it is active? Then in this case, the dove is actually the most vulnerable. It can be threatened by all four sides. Sasha: I like Zoey's idea. That is easy to see with what we have. If it is covered, then it is not active, and if it s adjacent, it is also not active. Evelyn: StarTree could you align the cost icons on the sides? StarTree: Done! Tanya: I think it is strange that the cost of a tile may affect other tiles but not itself. Maybe the name of the title should be near the top, so that the offer icons can be at the bottom near the cost icons. Sasha: Or should the cost icons be at the top? Black: I think the icons should orient to face the center the tile. StarTree: StarTree did something! There are now arrows pointing at what is affected. Evelyn: I like this design. 😊 Zoey: Does this mean you have to clean up after the doves? XD Tanya: If you want to use the dove. You don't need to clean up if you just want to use the post office. Sasha: Since the roads are collected... What do you all think if this means you need to clean up on all connected road if you want to use any icon on the connected roads? Zoey: No. XD The costs should be local only to the tile it is pointing at, else there is too much to check. Tanya: I am okay either way. Remember that in our current rules, the players do not need to place a tile next to an existing one. I think it makes it more interesting if the effect could spread through connected regions. Zoey: But all the roads will be connected. One card will shut down the entire road network. XD Tanya: That makes the quest urgent without explicitly saying so. I think that is a plus. Sasha: StarTree could you make the edge of the road not dark? It will make it easier to see connected regions. StarTree: Roger! Evelyn: I am surprised that the cards look okay even when they don't have graphics yet. Sasha: That is too early for me to say. I don't think you would want to see the whole town just in a yellow tone. Then the question is what happens if there are roofs of other color. Tanya: I am find with the whole town look like this on the map. It is a map. StarTree: Townhouse card is added! Tanya: If the roof colors are different, does it mean that their issues will be separate? Black: The amenities icon should face toward the center of the tile, not the bottom of the card. StarTree: Fixed! Sasha: Could you make the townhouses have orange roofs? Tanya: Could you also make the bridge to be on top so that the separate building can have its own cost? StarTree: Should there be a cost to that even when it has no amenity icon? And which cost icon should it have? Tanya: Make the same cost apply to all three: The Townhouse, the road, and the smaller house. StarTree: Roger! Sasha: StarTree please make a green roof building next, then a blue roof building. StarTree: Roger! StarTree: The library only has two cost icons. What should happen to the third cost slot? Sasha: Just add a dove there. StarTree: Roger! Tanya: How about a book pointing elsewhere? I means that someone needs to return a book. Sasha: That's funny. Let do that. Evelyn: I think one of the costs for a library should be books. Sasha: I think a library has more problem of having too many books than not having enough. Could you add a book as cost but point away? StarTree: Roger! LRRH: I think the amenity icons are too small. Tanya: Isn't the book cost point at the street pointless if the library book icon is active? Say you have the book cost icon pointing at the post office. What does that mean? Sasha: It means that the post office icon is disabled until the book cost icon becomes covered. To cover that, the players would need to play a tile on top to cover the cost icons. Black: If the book cost icon is shown, usually the bloom icon is also shown, meaning the library's book icon is not active. Sasha: With a hero, if you need to get a book from the library, your hero needs to have the knowledge icon and the bloom icon. Until the cost bar is covered, then any hero can go get a book. Tanya: I see. StarTree: If the amenities icons are bigger, they can only be near the four corners or they could be partially covered. Is it okay if they can be partially covered? LRRH: If they are big you can still see what it is. Tanya: It doesn't matter if they are partially covered, since being adjacent already means the icon is disabled. Being partially covered would mean just the same. Disabled. StarTree: Roger! Made Paladin Hall with bigger amenity icons! Tanya: I think the bigger icons look better, and the banner text should be slightly bigger also. StarTree: Roger! Made Paladin Hall with bigger amenity icons! LRRH: What if the cost bar is red? Or at least for issues that are urgent? StarTree: Done for comparison! Evelyn: I think that looks too stressful. 😅 Sasha: I think it is fine if the amenity icons are all facing the same direction. And let's not use that dirt green roof color. The roof colors will be either yellow, green, blue, brown, orange, purple, or red. StarTree: Remaking Freedom Plaza. Evelyn: With the bigger icon, it seems find for a title to be more colorful. Sasha: If a builder does not have a default icon, please make it brown. Any only those buildings should be brown. StarTree: Roger! Tanya: The library shouldn't have a town bell. It could be a clock instead. StarTree: Roger! Sasha: Funny how you can't easily simulate an "independent" island because you can't make just part a card to be on a lower layer. Evelyn: I'm sorry. 😖 Ledia: Should tile cards don't have cost bar? A building is just a building. If you want a building to be a library, you place the library icon there. Sasha: I think if the cost is not attached, there would be too many components. Ledia: Then what is the plan with the brown roof buildings? Sasha: For expansions or campaigns where there could be a token making the building. But that shouldn't be the default. The base game should have the icons printed on the tiles already. If you want you can always just print the tiles without the icons. Sasha: StarTree please make Mira Mira with a purple roof. StarTree: Roger! Evelyn: Could we have a version without the location name banner for comparison? StarTree: Roger! StarTree: Which one look better? With or without banner text? LRRH: I think they both look fine. But Mira Mira and Townhouse cards shouldn't have the icon in the middle of the road. StarTree: Tweaking. Making checker background for the cost bar. Making Market card.
@Happy is now Rank B4.

P4 thinks 3B's Queue should have something. Why is it empty?
Sasha: On one hand there is A LOT we need drawn, but on the other hand, the game is still in prototype, so it doesn't feel right to just ask 3B to draw what we might not end up using... P4: But you asked StarTree to prototype. Sasha: The graphics don't need to be final quality for prototype. Most of the time we don't even need graphics... Vivi: The latest tiles for playtest don't seem functional. The background seems more distracting than helpful. Especially when you compare to the forest tile drawn with just icons. Sasha: I think it would take too long to have a playtest if we finish every tile before doing so. Does the tile card with icon give you enough faith that the final card will look fine? Vivi: Not until I can see one functional card that is drawn. Black: is the concern that the drawn version will be too much like "Where's Waldo", where we would have a hard time seeing the icons we need to see quickly? Tanya: I thought that was the point for item cards. It was supposed to be like spot-it or finding waldo. Sasha: There are icons on the item cards but they are arranged quite nicely. I think they actually help the player remember what is on the card. Evelyn: I think so too. They are not entirely like spot it. They are not being tricky. 3B: The reference style of Adventure Begins doesn't have any icon on the tiles. The "icons" will just be the hero minis. Sasha: StarTree could you make a mock card with an icon over an Adventure Begins tile? StarTree: Roger! {"cmd":"url","url":"https://henning.artstation.com/projects/ykAxQn","desc":"🔗Credits"} Tanya: I think the tile is functional with the mock background. Record
 {"id":"202401192145","parentid":"202208250038","parentname":"Cardinal Quest","icon":"💟","title":"Gratitude Nomination","subtitle":"Record","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2020/04/22/11/59/thank-you-5077738_1280.jpg","music":"","author":"Evelyn","description":"","card-text":""}
⭐
There is now an updated game layout diagram!
Vivi: Do you mean at the start of the game, there is a town deck, a quest deck, a pile of all tiles face up, and none of the players have any card in hand? Sasha: Yes. A pile of tile cards is only about 30. I think it is manageable. Vivi: So the game starts with a pile of cards, and the players take turn putting two tiles next to each other in order to draw a town card, which will hopefully give them an icon they could use instead of discarding tiles? Sasha: They don't directly get the town cards that they draw. It is just available to be obtained if they can meet the card's cost. Vivi: It seems that it is too random and takes too long in the beginning for the players to get the right card. Tanya: Not if the tile cards form a reasonable puzzle. Black: It doesn't look like this game can finish in one or half hour. Should there be a starter card with no cost but offers something that is just free? In Splendor the player could at least draw gems. Now there are no gems. Sasha: Right now each tile has at least one or more costs. I don't think we are trying to intentionally make the tiles a puzzle. The costs and amenities should just be reasonable for the location.
Wee~~!
