⭐
This is about the living game aspect of the Arcacian Quest design
Black: Recently in a discussion I got to a concept that, many people originally has a good moral compass, but the more (bad) law they learn and accept, the more broken their moral compass would become when they subconsciously recalibrate their moral compass with a bad reference (bad law). And, when that happens, people turn into the proverbial crabs in a bucket that would drag down a crab trying to escape. Black: The education part of AQ should be able to include these concepts, but what cards should they be? Evelyn: I think "moral compass" should be an item. Tanya: A crab that can turn other people into crabs should be a recurring issue, so a complication card to be applied to a quest, a hero, or a place. To lift the curse would require lightning and healing. Or a compass would be destroyed. Black: I like that idea, maybe the name of the crab can suggest that is a bucket crab or a magnetic crab. Evelyn: I hope the card will not suggest that we are killing wildlife. 😅 Tanya: We'll see when the card is made. Zoey: Complication cards are called "add-on" cards. Maybe they should be called "adds". XD Ivy: The term is called Crab Mentality, if you want to be specific so a curious player has the correct turn to look up. {"cmd":"url","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crab_mentality","desc":"🔗"} Zoey: Could we add "Soothing bubbles" as an attack by the crabs? It makes people accept injustice and the nicer a hero the more susceptible they are to get KO'ed. Sasha: This is lit! Tanya: StarTree please make cards for review. StarTree: Roger! Evelyn: I think maybe there should also be an addon card "The law is wrong". If the heroes don't realize they could fail the quest. Zoey: #thelawiswrong XD Evelyn: It would affect those who know the law but without a working moral compass.
🍀 Moral Compass
⭐StarTree: Should the Moral Compass card replace the card at 202207282137|Moralism? Black: I think the new card is better, so yes. StarTree: How many stars should a Moral Compass have? Tanya: If a moral compass can convert hostiles, then it should have 5 stars. Black: Based on the flavor text, I would say this moral compass is not strong enough to convert hostiles. If you have this, it is just an intuition that make you sense injustice. But if you can't explain the principles, it can only prevent you from doing bad, but can't stop others from doing bad. The start rating should be at most 3 stars. Zoey: Then it can't be three stars because only you can sense it, you can't show it for other to sense even if they want to. It should be a one-star item. Black: One star is fine. Evelyn: Where would be a good place to list the meaning of the star rating? Tanya: We only described that in chat. The description should be in Game Terms. Evelyn: Could it be near the list of item cards? Tanya: I think that would be better maybe each card type should be its own big section in Track 3. StarTree: Moving the Item Cards section out. Adding star rating explanation Evelyn: Thank you. 🤗 Sasha: One down. Go StarTree! StarTree: Wee~~!
🍀 Crab Mentality
⭐6 StarTree: Making icons and card! Adding starting flavor text.
Tanya: I think Crab Mentality card needs its own node, there we can explain what the card means and how to defeat it. StarTree: Roger! 202401212041|🦀 Tanya: Could you make a companion card, or maybe that could be the back side of the card that explains the crab's abilities? Sasha: I think the back of the card needs to be the same, so the players don't know the card until they draw it. Evelyn: Adventure Begins has double sided cards. Sasha: There is a rotating GM. Zoey: That crab card is so anti me. When can I get lightning arrows? XD StarTree: Moving out the addon card section, reformatting.
🍀 The Law Is Wrong
⭐StarTree: Making a hole icon as a loop hole!
Black: A "loophole" is not a hole on the ground. It was a an arrow slit. StarTree: 😭 StarTree doesn't know what to put! Tanya: I don't think that historical reference is relevant anymore except as a trivia. Sasha: You could still use a hole icon, just don't mention "loophole". StarTree: Roger! StarTree: Making more icons. Adding text. StarTree: What should be the icons for fixing the hole? Tanya: Crystal Ball, Compass, Briefcase. StarTree: Should this be a 2-star or 4-star add-on? Tanya: I think a loophole doesn't exist because no one saw it. You could expect resistance. So 4-star. Black: I think the solution should use a scale instead of a compass. Tanya: I think it should be a compass. You are not weighing and comparing. You just need to know what is correct. Black: Okay. Evelyn: I think "Addon" cards such as the crabs and this card should have a stop sign icon instead of the red plus icon. I think that will make them more clear that they are obstacles. Tanya: Good idea. StarTree: Is the stop sign icon this: 🛑 ? Should it be used instead of the "NO" icon: 🚫 ? Evelyn: Could you use the one that looks better? StarTree: The Noto stop sign does not look good because it is just a red octagon. At a distance it looks like a circle! Evelyn: I'm sorry. 😖 Black: I think for the loophole card you can use an alarm. Tanya: I think a loophole does not have enough urgency to use a siren. Maybe just the push pin. StarTree: Roger! Zoey: Is an Addon card considered a quest card? Tanya: All quest cards that do not have a rank letter would be an add-on. When it is drawn while you think you have completed a quest, it means that the quest is not done. Evelyn: I think the pin icon looks good. StarTree: Updating 202307161217|Loophole node format and add card!
@Board is now Rank B5.
Zoey: When an obstacle card has stars, do your items need enough stars to overcome them? Zoey: The compass card is a one-star card. Is it not applicable to fix the loophole or do you just need others cards with star and add them up? Sasha: I think only one card needs to have enough stars. Evelyn: Could you use an item that is not required but has enough stars along with the required items? Sasha: I have to think about it. Black: I think for the sake of a live game, the locations/tile cards are not live enough. Sasha: isn't that just a matter of graphics? Tanya: What do you want to see in a tile or place card? Black: I think what I am trying to say is, if we map out own guild as tiles, the tiles should allow us to see where there are quests. Tanya: We have quests at the harbor. Black: How does having a tile or place card help in the live game? Tanya: The tile card should have what the facility offers and up to three things the facility needs. In a live game, the harbor would be attached with its costs covered unless the harbor is affected in such a way that it cannot function. Black: You mean like a power outage? Tanya: That could be one of the costs, but power outage is so common it could just be an addon. Black: StarTree could you make a harbor tile where electricity is a requirement? StarTree: Roger!
Wee~~!

⭐
This is a similar topic as yesterday, but this time about strawman arguments.
Black: If we follow the same style as last time, a strawman is an add. A way to defeat it is to use a matrix to show the context of discussion, and where the strawman is being made. Black: For the matrix, maybe it could be a checker shield. StarTree: Making a Checker Shield card! StarTree: What should be the star rating of the shield? Tanya: Four-star. I don't think it will work against hostiles. It can block hostile strawman but cannot convert the attacker. StarTree: Roger! StarTree: Upgrading the strawman node. LRRH: Could add cards be darker? They look too much like item cards. StarTree: StarTree will try something! StarTree: What Icons should the strawman card have? Tanya: I think strawman would block crystal ball. If someone is using strawman, and you respond in hypotheticals, then the strawman become legit because the scope of discussion now includes hypotheticals. Zoey: You are not suppose to attack the strawman, which will let the discussion go off track. So also no attacks. Tanya: Could you change the pin icon to the pumpkin? StarTree: Roger! Evelyn: The strawman card looks really cute. 😍 Evelyn: モンスターだけど 😖 Zoey: XD
Wee~~!

⭐
This is not entirely related to AQ, but I think the content can be unpacked for AQ.
Question at Nextdoor
Black: This scenario originated from a thread at Nextdoor asking which driver should be at fault in the following situation.
Black: Car 1 is backing out of a slanted row of parking spaces in a parking lot, while Car 2 is going down against the expected flow of traffic. The back of the backing car collides with the side of the car trying to go through. Black: To show the situation, I want some graphics support. StarTree: Roger! {"cmd":"url","url":"https://github.com/MagicBakery/Images/blob/main/20240123-Collision.png?raw=true","desc":"🔗"} Amelia: Blue's fault. Gaia: Blue is the most at fault. He saw yellow backing up and should prepare to protect himself. 44: Same. Zoey: It turned into a Law Game. XD Black: Added slides where one of them is on foot, but with the same state of mind. {"cmd":"url","url":"https://github.com/MagicBakery/Images/blob/main/20240123-Collision_2.png?raw=true","desc":"🔗"} {"cmd":"url","url":"https://github.com/MagicBakery/Images/blob/main/20240123-Collision_3.png","desc":"🔗"} Tanya: I think the posting at Nextdoor would give you Rank S on the traditional scale to the chapter of your choice.
@Arena is now Rank S4.
Tanya: The reenactment slides could be a 5-star solution. I think it is capable of forcing hostile actors to conform. Black: I am not sure what item "reenactment" would be. Maybe a picture frame? I think this technique is about locking down the context to discuss a concept. It is about framing the scenario. Evelyn: I think the part that helps, also, is that you are using the same set of questions to analyze when you change the context. I think having a set of fixed question is part of the solution.
To be continued...

🔔
The law game continues. Sasha: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[379] Extortion Part 2
📯Sasha: This is a revisit of this topic from last time. if Bob suggested to Ann to pay for her manicure in exchange for Ann to not tell Bob's wife, Ann would not be guilty of extortion. Why would it change if Ann was the one making the offer? If Bob didn't want to trade, Bob could just decline. Ann is not "forcing" Bob to comply.
Tanya: From last time, it depends on if Ann is acting in malice. Sasha: But from the description Ann does not act in malice. She thought Bob might want to trade and made an offer. How is that malice? Gaia: Ann is greedy. Sasha: But what if Bob wants to trade but didn't dare to ask? Ann wouldn't know whether Bob is willing until they talk. Why would Ann be guilty for just asking and trying to understand Bob's interest? 44: Is it because it depends on who is asking? Sasha: Should it? If Bob says no and Ann keeps asking, that could be harassment. But why can't Ann ask even the first time? Evelyn: Wasn't it because Ann would be helping Bob lie to the wife? Sasha: If you want to hold Ann guilty for that Ann would be guilty even if she chose to keep the secret without talking to Bob. Then why does she get more guilt if she simply talk to Bob about it? Tanya: I think that is a good point. Maybe Ann should not be additionally guilty if she is acting out of a cooperative state of mind than being malicious. Black: I think it might depend on what information Ann is trying to disclose. If the information is about cheating, then Ann would be guilty of withholding that from Ann, and guily if she conspires with Bob. If she makes an offer to Bob, she would be guilty of solicitation. If Bob makes an offer to Ann, Bob would be guilty of solicitation. If they agree, they would both be guilty of conspiracy. Tanya: Then even making an offer could be a crime. Black: The difference between a normal offer and this offer is that the offer to withhold the truth violates the wife's autonomy. If the withholding of information would not violate anyone's right, then maybe it would just be a trade. Tanya: That means if Ann happens to know Bob's passwords, if Ann offer Bob to pay her in exchange of keeping his passwords a secret, Ann would be guilty of extortion. Sasha: Then what kind of offer is not blackmail? Black: Maybe when Ann knows what the wife likes and offer to sell it to Bob? If that information is not meant to be a secret but Bob didn't know how to ask. Sasha: So you mean for a blackmail to happen, the piece of information needs to be something that a person has a right to keep secret, or a piece of information someone has a right to know. Black: Yes. Black: So when Bob offer to Ann, Bob is guilty, but the crime is not extortion but solicitation or bribery. Tanya: Yes. 44: Doesn't bribery require making a competition unfair? Black: Regardless what it is called, it should be at least morally bad for either of them to plan to hide the true from the wife. "Bribery" is just the closet word I can think of.
@Gaia is now Rank A4. This is game 6 in 2024!

{"name":"James","score":"1"}, {"name":"Ivy","score":"1"}, {"name":"P4","score":"1"} ]}
⭐
There was a comment on using the position of impact to determine who is at fault.
Position of Impact
Black: This is for making another slide to address the judgment of using the position of impact to determine who is at fault.
Sasha: I don't get why we are doing this. Their argument is so bad. Black: I think if we are defending a concept, we need to fairly address why other concepts fail. Black: And a slide is much more clear than just a block of text. Black: How about we go around and say why that idea is bad? Sasha: Because if a driver is trying to squeeze through, it doesn't matter how the cars hit. The point is that the driver decided to squeeze through a path expected the other driver to avoid them, while knowing that the other driver is unaware of their action. That makes them a willful risk taker. They are not eligible to claim any damage they incur on themself by deciding to take a risk. Black: But that answer is just addressing what the correct answer should be. You didn't address why it is wrong. Sasha: Because if the cars happens to end up a certain way, the position method would say that the innocent car is at fault. Black: I think that is not a strong argument because they could just say, "but that is correct, the other car should be at fault." Tanya: I think you can argue based on unintended consequences and universality. Tanya: Unintended consequence: If that law is known, when Blue decides to squeeze through, Blue knows for certain that as long as they are fast enough they would take less of a blame if the two cars collide. This encourages Blue to gas it as hard as they can. At the same time, Yellow seeing Blue coming, would also accelerate to close the path to prevent its own car from scraping Blue's side. The result is that the law would incentivies unsafe behavior that wouldn't exist before. Tanya: Universality: Safety laws are supposed to be general. So if you replace the Blue car with a cannon ball, you know it is the shooter who is at fault, regardless where the ball hits the other car. Evelyn: I think people won't understand the cannon ball analogy. Maybe change it to a soccer ball. Tanya: Soccer ball doesn't do any damage, how about a baseball? Black: I think if you use baseball, the reader would assume there is someone on the other side, and the car is the one interrupting their practice. Tanya: But you would still stop throwing. Black: How about just a brick test. Some guy trying to throw a brick they don't want down the aisle. Tanya: Same to me. Sasha: Can you even fit so much on a page? How about just one reason? Tanya: How about we just list all criticisms in text? I think it is better if we list all of them. Black: Looks like I can only fit three criticisms. Black: Actually, the criticisms based on orientation of impact and who is backing up are about the same. So I would just copy and make two judgment sheets.
To be continued...
{"type":"chat","id":"202401292240","parentid":"202312251111","parentname":"Arcacian Quest","icon":"📯","title":"Live Game: Position of Impact","prev":"202401282054","author":"Black","location":"Game Room"}

⭐
We are going to make another slide about backing up because there is a really funny rebuttal.
Rebuttal
Black: One of the claims is that the one backing up should be at fault. Then what if Blue is also backing up?
Tanya: I don't think their argument is about "backing", but backing out to the road from a side location. So showing both cars backing up would not change their decision since only Yellow is backing out. Black: Okay. Then let's make a slide on what an ideal outcome is because it seems that the other participants are thinking inside the box. Black: Making Slide 15. Tanya: That is a good slide. With that you don't need to attack the other candidate system. They are completely out-ranked. Black: I think by now I won't be too surprise if they do something unexpected. Tanya: True. Sasha: As much as I dislike this thread, Slide 15 is satisfying. This is a good move and there should be an item for it. Ledia: Isn't this just Provoke, but in a more heroic way? You took center stage and say, "this is what you need to fight against." Fina: Challenge. Black: How about a "Tower Shield of Challenge"? Zoey: I like how you even told them not to settle for 90%, but they still did it. This is too dramatic. XD Sasha: Yet another shield? How about full armor? Defender's Armor Tanya: I think, if they don't have a counter candidate, they would just laugh. Black: I think full armor is fine. Flavor text: "If you want to be considered, you must at least beat this." Tanya: That sounds like an upgraded version of the checker training shield. I think this is worth 5-star. Black: Should the armor use the color scheme of the aggression scale? That is from white to red to black. Zoey: That looks so much like a bad guy though. XD Evelyn: I think the content isn't so much about aggression but justice. Zoey: I don't think this is Kirito Midnight cloak moment. The armor should look like a good guy. Shining, blindingly shining good. XD Black: Armor of Justice, same flavor text or "If you want to be considered, you should at least be just." Fina: You could make more than one set of armor, but I would like to see a Champion's Armor, which is the defending champion. The flavor text can be the original one, "This is what you need to beat." On the tower shield you could list the icons such as Shield, Crystal Ball, Scale, and Trumpet. Evelyn: I like that idea. Zoey: Me too. XD Black: Then Champion's Armor first. StarTree: Queued for 3B!
To be continued...

This is a routine monthly status update for Cardinal Quest.
📯StarTree: There are 6 open quests, 330 quest hours, 57 side quests, 5 prep quests, and 58 unresolved failures remaining! Tanya: Please process the prep quests. StarTree: Should we also track and report TPK of other teams? Tanya: Yes. StarTree: Roger! Sasha: Hold on. Are you going to mark other team's TPK differently? StarTree: How should StarTree mark them? Tanya: TBK StarTree: Roger! Tanya: Now on to TPK records.
2308 Dojo
🎩StarTree: For the Dojo quest, we finished without the Shoji screens. Hospitalian Knights finished the quest!
Tanya: Why did we miss the screens? StarTree: They didn't ask for them! Hospitalian Knights said the quest was wrong and we should know that the dojo needed the barrier screens! Tanya: I see.
Tanya thanks all for questing. @Cardinal is now Rank B3.

Safe Designs
📯 Hard Brake Horn Black: This is a feature where when the horn is sound when a driver hard brakes a car in motion. The driver's hands are controlling the steering wheel. They don't have another hand to use the horn.
📯 Car Bells Black: This is an idea of having another horn that the driver can use, the sound would be similar to a bike bell and each to use at the steering wheel.

🔔
It seems that "Arcacianism" has over a thousand hits at Google.
Sasha: That must be a glitch... It had never went above 100 hits. Natalie: And the GitHub page is the first search result. I didn't need to click on "I really meant to search for Arcacianism." Zoey: And that came after not discussing it for a month. It seems something is better left alone. XD Ledia: It took some effort to put it on a sitemap. Sasha: As I said, this is probably a glitch. So don't celebrate yet. Arcacianism still only has one hitpoint. Natalie: Actually "show all" only lists 929 hits. That hasn't broken 1000 hits. Black: I think it is a significant milestone that you can now search for Arcacianism directly. Tanya: Yes. Sasha: Let's not be overjoyed and keep going. Zoey: Sasha is being skeptical. XD Black: I wonder if there was something specific that we did that allowed this. Tanya: The GitHub page is now the first link, so it is probably the sitemap.
[2/8 Hits] Monthly Sitemap Update
🔍Sasha: If I count the hits, the only two hits are the Arcacianism node and Sitemap nodes. Despite the sitemap has 8 links.
Sasha: Let's add two more links to the sitemap nonetheless. StarTree: StarTree will add the Playlist and Arcacian Quest nodes! StarTree: Uploaded. The sitemap was last read on 2024-01-28 and discovered 8 pages. Now it says it has discovered 10 pages. @Detective is now Rank S1.

  1. Understand your audience {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*1"}
  2. Define your goal {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*2"}
  3. Research your topic {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*3"}
  4. Write an outline (start thinking about visuals) {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*4"}
  5. Draft a script (open with a relevant story) {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*5"}
  6. Practice reading the script out loud {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*6"}
  7. Experiment with your voice {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*7"}
  8. Incorporate hand gestures and choreographed hand motions {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*8"}
  9. Get live feedback from a small group if possible {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*9"}
  10. Revise the script {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*10"}
  11. Memorize your speech (but don't be afraid to go off script) {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*11"}
  12. Practice often - when you think you're ready, practice again {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*12"}
  13. Allow for questions and prepare answers {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*13"}
  14. Field questions with a tursted friend/mentor {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*14"}
  15. Conduct breathing exercises before your speech {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*15"}
  16. Present with confidence, but leave arrogance at home {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*16"}
  17. Make eye contact and engage {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*17"}
  18. Keep going if you stumble {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*18"}
  19. If you go off script, come back to where you left off {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*19"}
  20. Close big and leave them wanting more {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.entrepreneur.com/leadership/the-complete-20-step-guide-to-ace-public-speaking/444042","desc":"*20"}

🔔
The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[390] Forgery
📯Natalie: Ann is a warehouse manager. She made a fake receipt that the warehouse had received a package that in fact was not received. Has Ann committed forgery?
Gaia: Yes. That is forgery. Sasha: This sounds like a trick question, is falsifying forgery? Zoey: Our notes just said forgery is complete when the document is falsified. So falsifying a document is forgery. Tanya: If you willfully make a document that is fake or has false information, then it is forgery. Natalie: The answer is that if Ann merely falsely signed that the goods are received, then it is misrepresentation. If Ann made a fake receipt, then it is forgery. Sasha: I knew it was a trick question!
📯 Navigation Upgrade
LRRH: The navigation at the Law Game node is getting unwieldly because the list is so long. Could it be made so that when you click on a topic it jumps to where the text is displayed?
StarTree: Roger! StarTree: Adding function ShowLP3NJ. Replacing the function in Law Game node. Testing. Done! Natalie: Thank you! StarTree: Wee~~!
@Paladin is now Rank B2. This is the first game in February 2024!
